#Awards
The awards were given to the players who stood out during the tournament.

* Most Valuable Player: Gabriela Guimarães (Brazil)
* Best Setter: Danielle Lins (Brazil)
* Best Outside Spikers: Gabriela Guimarães (Brazil) and Miriam Sylla (Italy)
* Best Middle Blockers: Ana Carolina da Silva (Brazil) and Jovana Stevanović (Serbia)
* Best Opposite Spiker: Tijana Bošković (Serbia)
* Best Libero: Monica De Gennaro (Italy)

#Statistics leaders
The statistics leaders were the players who led the tournament in various categories.

* Best Scorer: Tijana Bošković (Serbia) - 182 points

article:
Big Brother Brasil 23

Big Brother Brasil 23 was the twenty-third season of the Brazilian reality television series Big Brother Brasil, which premiered on January 16, 2023, on Rede Globo. The show was produced by John de Mol and hosted by Tiago Leifert. The season concluded on April 4, 2023, with Gabriel Santana being crowned the winner.

# The game

The game of Big Brother Brasil 23 featured a number of twists and changes to the traditional format of the show.

## Final prize change throughout the season

The final prize of the season was R$1.5 million, but it was subject to change throughout the season based on the performance of the housemates.

## Super HoH

The Super HoH was a special power that gave the holder the ability to nominate two housemates for eviction instead of the usual one. This power was introduced in week 4 and was won by Gabriel Santana.

## Withdrawal Button

The Withdrawal Button was a feature that allowed a housemate to withdraw from the competition and leave the house voluntarily. This feature was introduced in week 6 and was used by one housemate.

### FeedBBB

FeedBBB was a social media feature that allowed viewers to interact with the show and influence the game. Viewers could vote for their favorite housemate and influence the outcome of certain challenges.

## Selective Collection

Selective Collection was a twist that allowed the housemates to collect a limited amount of food and supplies from the storage room. This twist was introduced in week 3 and added an extra layer of strategy to the game.

## Evicted's Message

Evicted's Message was a feature that allowed an evicted housemate to leave a message for the remaining housemates. This feature was introduced in week 2 and added a new level of drama to the show.

## Glass House

The Glass House was a special area of the house that was visible to the public. Housemates who entered the Glass House had to perform a task in front of a live audience.

## Duos Twist

The Duos Twist was a feature that paired two housemates together as a team. This twist was introduced in week 5 and added a new level of strategy to the game.

## Secret Room

The Secret Room was a hidden area of the house that was not visible to the other housemates. One housemate was given access to the Secret Room and was able to gather information about the other housemates.

## Higher Power

The Higher Power was a special power that gave the holder the ability to influence the game in a significant way. This power was introduced in week 7 and was won by Larissa Santos.

## White Room

The White Room was a special area of the house that was designed to be a peaceful and relaxing space. Housemates who entered the White Room had to perform a task in a calm and peaceful manner.

## Housemate Exchange

The Housemate Exchange was a feature that allowed two housemates to switch places in the house. This twist was introduced in week 8 and added a new level of drama to the show.

## Repechage Twist

The Repechage Twist was a feature that allowed an evicted housemate to return to the game. This twist was introduced in week 9 and added a new level of excitement to the show.

## Vote to Save

The Vote to Save was a feature that allowed viewers to vote for their favorite housemate and save them from eviction. This feature was introduced in week 10 and gave viewers a greater level of control over the game.

## Power of Veto

The Power of Veto was a special power that gave the holder the ability to veto a nomination. This power was introduced in week 11 and was won by Gabriel Santana.

## Joker Power

The Joker Power was a special power that gave the holder the ability to play a joke on another housemate. This power was introduced in week 12 and was won by Larissa Santos.

## Power of No

The Power of No was a special power that gave the holder the ability to say no to a task or challenge. This power was introduced in week 13 and was won by Gabriel Santana.

## Big Phone

The Big Phone was a feature that allowed housemates to communicate with the outside world. This feature was introduced in week 14 and added a new level of drama to the show.

## The Counterattack

The Counterattack was a feature that allowed housemates to counterattack against another housemate. This feature was introduced in week 15 and added a new level of strategy to the game.

# Voting history

## Notes

Russian Invasion of Ukraine

The Russian invasion of Ukraine is an ongoing military conflict that began on February 24, 2022, when Russia launched a large-scale invasion of Ukraine. The conflict has resulted in significant human suffering, displacement, and economic disruption, and has drawn international attention and condemnation.

# Background

## Post-Soviet relations

Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Ukraine and Russia established diplomatic relations, with Ukraine declaring independence and Russia recognizing it as a sovereign state. However, the relationship between the two countries has been complex and often tense, with disputes over territory, energy resources, and cultural identity.

## Ukrainian revolution, Russian intervention in Crimea and Donbas

In 2014, a popular uprising in Ukraine led to the ousting of President Viktor Yanukovych, who was seen as pro-Russian. Russia responded by annexing Crimea, a Ukrainian peninsula with strategic military importance, and supporting separatist movements in the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk. The conflict in eastern Ukraine, known as the Donbas War, has resulted in thousands of deaths and displaced millions of people.

# Prelude

## Putin's invasion announcement

On February 24, 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a "special military operation" in Ukraine, citing concerns about the security of Russian-speaking populations in eastern Ukraine and the need to "demilitarize and denazify" Ukraine. The announcement marked the beginning of a large-scale invasion of Ukraine, with Russian forces launching attacks on multiple fronts.

# Events

## Initial invasion (24 February – 7 April)

### Kyiv and northern front

However, Ukrainian forces put up significant resistance, and the Russian advance was slowed. The city was subjected to intense shelling and bombing, causing widespread damage and civilian casualties.

Russian forces also launched an attack on the northeastern city of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city. The city was heavily shelled, and Ukrainian forces fought back, but Russian forces made gains in the surrounding areas.

### Southern front

Russian forces launched an attack on the southern city of Mariupol, a strategic port city on the Sea of Azov. The city was heavily shelled, and Ukrainian forces fought back, but Russian forces eventually captured the city.

### Eastern front

Russian forces launched an attack on the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, where separatist movements had been active since 2014. The conflict in the region intensified, with both sides suffering heavy losses.

After a prolonged siege, Mariupol fell to Russian forces on May 20, 2022. The city suffered significant damage, and thousands of civilians were trapped or displaced.

### Fall of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk

## Russian annexations and occupation losses (6 September – 11 November 2022)

On September 30, 2022, Russia annexed the Donetsk, Kherson, Luhansk, and Zaporizhzhia oblasts, citing the results of referendums held in the regions. The annexation was widely condemned by the international community.

### Zaporizhzhia front

Ukrainian forces launched a counterattack in the Zaporizhzhia region in October 2022, pushing Russian forces back and recapturing several villages and towns.

### Kharkiv counteroffensive

Ukrainian forces launched a counterattack in the Kharkiv region in November 2022, pushing Russian forces back and recapturing several villages and towns.

## Winter stalemate, attrition campaign and military surge (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)

### Battle of Bakhmut

The Battle of Bakhmut began in November 2022 and continued into 2023, with both sides suffering heavy losses. The battle was one of the bloodiest of the conflict, with both sides using significant resources and manpower.

2023–24 Indian Super League

The 2023–24 Indian Super League season, also known as Hero Indian Super League for sponsorship reasons, is the tenth season of the Indian Super League, the top division of association football in India. The season began on 20 September 2023 and is scheduled to end on 25 March 2024.

Changes from last season
------------------------

The 2023–24 season sees several changes from the previous season. The league has expanded to 12 teams, with the addition of two new teams, Punjab FC and Sudeva Delhi FC. The season also sees the introduction of a new playoff format, with the top six teams qualifying for the playoffs.

Teams
-----

2022–23 Premier League

The 2022–23 Premier League is the 31st season of the Premier League, the top English professional league for association football clubs since its establishment in 1992. The season started on 5 August 2022 and is scheduled to conclude on 28 May 2023.

# Summary

The 2022–23 Premier League season is the first to feature a winter break, which will take place in February 2023. This break was introduced to allow players to rest and recover during the busy winter period. The season will also see the introduction of new rules, including the use of concussion substitutes and changes to the handball rule.

## Developments

The league has also announced a new partnership with the English Football League (EFL) to improve the development of young players.

India at the 2022 Commonwealth Games

The 2022 Commonwealth Games, officially known as the XXII Commonwealth Games, were held in Birmingham, England, from July 28 to August 8, 2022. India, a founding member of the Commonwealth Games Federation, sent a contingent of athletes to participate in the multi-sport event.

#Withdrawal threat

In the months leading up to the Games, there were concerns that India might withdraw from the event due to a dispute over the inclusion of shooting sports, in which India has historically excelled. However, after negotiations with the Commonwealth Games Federation, India confirmed its participation in the Games.

#Competitors

India sent a total of 210 athletes to compete in 15 sports at the 2022 Commonwealth Games. The team was led by flag bearer Manpreet Singh, the captain of the Indian men's hockey team.

#Medals

India won a total of 61 medals at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 22 gold medals, 16 silver medals, and 23 bronze medals. This was India's fifth-best performance at the Commonwealth Games, behind its performances in 2010, 2002, 2006, and 2018.

#Medalists

India's medalists at the 2022 Commonwealth Games included:

* Achinta Sheuli (weightlifting, gold)
* Bajrang Punia (wrestling, gold)
* Bhavina Patel (para table tennis, gold)
* Jeremy Lalrinnunga (weightlifting, gold)
* Mirabai Chanu (weightlifting, gold)
* Nayanmoni Saikia (lawn bowls, gold)
* Nikhat Zareen (boxing, gold)
* Ravi Kumar Dahiya (wrestling, gold)
* Sakshi Malik (wrestling, gold)
* Sharath Kamal (table tennis, gold)
* Vinesh Phogat (wrestling, gold)

##Athletics

India won a total of 8 medals in athletics at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal, 4 silver medals, and 3 bronze medals. The gold medal was won by Neeraj Chopra in the men's javelin throw event.

##Badminton

India won a total of 6 medals in badminton at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 3 gold medals, 1 silver medal, and 2 bronze medals. The gold medals were won by PV Sindhu in the women's singles event, Lakshya Sen in the men's singles event, and the pair of Satwiksairaj Rankireddy and Chirag Shetty in the men's doubles event.

##Boxing

India won a total of 7 medals in boxing at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 3 gold medals, 2 silver medals, and 2 bronze medals. The gold medals were won by Nikhat Zareen in the women's 50 kg event, Amit Panghal in the men's 51 kg event, and Nitu Ghanghas in the women's 45 kg event.

##Cricket

India won the gold medal in the women's cricket tournament at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, defeating Australia in the final.

##Cycling

###Track

India won a total of 1 medal in track cycling at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, a bronze medal won by the team of Ronaldo Singh, Raju Bati, and David Beckham in the men's team sprint event.

##Gymnastics

###Artistic

India won a total of 1 medal in artistic gymnastics at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, a bronze medal won by Pranati Nayak in the women's vault event.

###Rhythmic

India won a total of 1 medal in rhythmic gymnastics at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, a bronze medal won by Bavleen Kaur in the women's all-around event.

##Hockey

###Men's tournament

India won the silver medal in the men's hockey tournament at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, losing to Australia in the final.

###Women's tournament

India won the bronze medal in the women's hockey tournament at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, defeating New Zealand in the third-place playoff.

##Judo

India won a total of 3 medals in judo at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal, 1 silver medal, and 1 bronze medal. The gold medal was won by Sushila Devi in the women's 48 kg event.

##Lawn bowls

India won a total of 2 medals in lawn bowls at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal and 1 silver medal. The gold medal was won by the pair of Nayanmoni Saikia and Lovely Choubey in the women's pairs event.

##Para powerlifting

India won a total of 4 medals in para powerlifting at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal, 2 silver medals, and 1 bronze medal. The gold medal was won by Sudhir in the men's heavyweight event.

##Squash

India won a total of 2 medals in squash at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal and 1 bronze medal. The gold medal was won by the pair of Dipika Pallikal and Saurav Ghosal in the mixed doubles event.

##Swimming

India won a total of 2 medals in swimming at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 silver medal and 1 bronze medal.

##Table tennis

India won a total of 4 medals in table tennis at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 1 gold medal, 2 silver medals, and 1 bronze medal. The gold medal was won by Sharath Kamal in the men's singles event.

##Triathlon

India won a total of 1 medal in triathlon at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, a bronze medal won by Adarsh Nandan Singh in the men's individual event.

India won a total of 10 medals in weightlifting at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, including 3 gold medals, 3 silver medals, and 4 bronze medals. The gold medals were won by Mirabai Chanu in the women's 49 kg event, Jeremy Lalrinnunga in the men's 67 kg event, and Achinta Sheuli in the men's 73 kg event.

article:
Instasamka

Instasamka is a Russian rapper, singer, and songwriter who has gained widespread recognition for her unique blend of hip-hop and pop music. Born and raised in Moscow, Instasamka rose to fame in the mid-2010s and has since become one of the most popular and influential musicians in Russia.

#Early life

Instasamka was born on February 19, 1992, in Moscow, Russia. Growing up in a creative family, she was exposed to music from an early age and began writing her own songs as a teenager. Instasamka's parents encouraged her passion for music, and she began performing at local concerts and events in her teenage years.

After completing her secondary education, Instasamka pursued a career in music, releasing her debut single in 2013. However, it was not until 2015 that she gained widespread recognition with the release of her debut album, "Instasamka".

#Career

Instasamka's music career began to take off in 2015 with the release of her debut album, which included the hit single "Mama". The album's success led to Instasamka being signed to a major record label, and she went on to release several successful albums and singles throughout the mid-2010s.

In 2016, Instasamka released her second album, "Insta Queen", which solidified her position as one of the leading figures in Russian hip-hop. The album included the hit singles "Insta Queen" and "Money", and went on to become one of the best-selling albums of the year.

Throughout her career, Instasamka has collaborated with numerous high-profile artists, including Russian rappers Noize MC and Basta, as well as international artists such as American rapper Lil Pump. She has also performed at numerous music festivals and concerts, including the annual VK Fest in St. Petersburg.

#Personal life

Instasamka is known for her outspoken and confident personality, and has become a role model for many young women in Russia. In addition to her music career, she is also a successful entrepreneur, having launched her own clothing line and makeup brand.

Instasamka has been open about her personal struggles, including her experiences with depression and anxiety. She has used her platform to raise awareness about mental health issues and to promote self-acceptance and body positivity.

#Discography

##Studio albums

* "Instasamka" (2015)
* "Insta Queen" (2016)
* "Money" (2018)
* "Queen of Rap" (2020)

##Remix albums

* "Instasamka: The Remixes" (2016)
* "Insta Queen: The Remixes" (2017)

#Preferences

Instasamka's music style is a unique blend of hip-hop and pop, with lyrics that often focus on themes of female empowerment, self-acceptance, and personal growth. She has cited artists such as Nicki Minaj and Lady Gaga as influences, and has been praised for her energetic live performances and catchy songwriting.

Instasamka is also known for her bold fashion sense, often incorporating bright colors and statement pieces into her music videos and live performances. She has been named as one of the best-dressed celebrities in Russia, and has collaborated with numerous fashion brands on limited-edition clothing lines.

2022 Welsh Open (snooker)

The 2022 Welsh Open was a professional snooker tournament that took place from 28 February to 6 March 2022 at the ICC Wales in Newport, Wales. It was the 31st edition of the Welsh Open and the 12th ranking event of the 2021-22 snooker season. The tournament was broadcast on ITV4 in the United Kingdom and on various other networks around the world.

#Format

The tournament was played as a 128-player knockout competition, with all matches being played as best-of-seven frames until the semi-finals, which were played as best-of-11 frames. The final was played as best-of-17 frames. The top 32 players in the world rankings were seeded and received a bye to the second round, while the remaining 96 players competed in the qualifying rounds.

##Prize fund

The total prize fund for the tournament was £405,000, with the winner receiving £70,000 and the runner-up receiving £35,000.

#Summary

The 2022 Welsh Open was a highly competitive tournament that featured many exciting matches and upsets.

##Early rounds

The early rounds of the tournament saw several seeded players lose to lower-ranked opponents. In the first round, world number 35 Ben Woollaston defeated world number 28 Martin Gould, while world number 42 Alexander Ursenbacher defeated world number 29 Liang Wenbo. In the second round, world number 17 Jack Lisowski lost to world number 80 Jamie Clarke, while world number 20 Ryan Day lost to world number 67 Robbie Williams.

##Last 16

The last 16 saw several high-quality matches, including a 4-3 win for world number 12 Mark Williams over world number 21 Gary Wilson. World number 14 Barry Hawkins also won 4-3, defeating world number 19 David Gilbert. World number 16 Anthony McGill won 4-2 against world number 32 Robert Milkins.

World number 14 Barry Hawkins also won 5-4, defeating world number 16 Anthony McGill. Super Bowl LVII Halftime Show

The Super Bowl LVII Halftime Show was the halftime entertainment for Super Bowl LVII, which took place on February 12, 2023, at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona. The show featured Rihanna as the main performer, marking her first live performance in over five years. The highly anticipated event was watched by millions of viewers worldwide, generating significant buzz on social media and in the entertainment industry.

#Background and overview

Rihanna was officially announced as the halftime show performer on September 25, 2022, by the National Football League (NFL), Roc Nation, and Apple Music. The selection of Rihanna as the headliner was seen as a significant coup for the NFL, given her immense popularity and reputation as a dynamic live performer. Rihanna had previously declined offers to perform at the Super Bowl in the past, making her eventual agreement to headline the event a major surprise.

The halftime show was produced by Roc Nation, founded by Jay-Z, in collaboration with the NFL and Apple Music. The production team worked closely with Rihanna to create a visually stunning and musically impressive performance that would showcase her extensive catalog of hits. The show's creative direction was led by Rihanna herself, along with Roc Nation's head of creative, Jesse Collins, and renowned choreographer, Parris Goebel.

#Reception

The Super Bowl LVII Halftime Show received widespread critical acclaim from music critics and entertainment journalists. Reviewers praised Rihanna's high-energy performance, which featured a mix of her biggest hits, including "Work," "Where Have You Been," and "Umbrella." The show's elaborate stage design, choreography, and visual effects were also widely praised.

#Commercial impact

Rihanna's halftime show performance also generated significant revenue from merchandise sales, with fans snapping up official merchandise featuring the show's logo and imagery.

article:
The Fabelmans
================

The Fabelmans is a 2022 American coming-of-age drama film written and directed by Steven Spielberg. The film is a semi-autobiographical account of Spielberg's own childhood and his early fascination with filmmaking. It stars Gabriel LaBelle, Michelle Williams, Paul Dano, Seth Rogen, and Judd Hirsch.

Plot
=====

The film tells the story of Sammy Fabelman, a young boy who grows up in post-war Arizona with a passion for filmmaking. Sammy's parents, Mitzi and Burt, are loving but struggling to make ends meet. His mother, a free-spirited woman, encourages Sammy's creativity, while his father, a practical engineer, wants him to focus on science and mathematics.

As Sammy grows older, he becomes increasingly fascinated with filmmaking, using his father's camera to make short films with his sisters and friends. However, his parents' marriage begins to fray, and Sammy struggles to cope with the changes in his family.

Cast
=====

* Gabriel LaBelle as Sammy Fabelman
* Michelle Williams as Mitzi Fabelman
* Paul Dano as Burt Fabelman
* Seth Rogen as Bennie Loewy
* Judd Hirsch as Uncle Boris
* Julia Butters as Reggie Fabelman
* Keeley Karsten as Natalie Fabelman
* Sophia Kopera as Lisa Fabelman

Production
==========

### Development

The Fabelmans was a long-gestating project for Spielberg, who had been thinking about making a film about his childhood for many years. In 2019, it was announced that Spielberg would be teaming up with writer and producer Tony Kushner to develop the project.

### Writing

Spielberg and Kushner worked closely together to develop the screenplay, which was heavily influenced by Spielberg's own memories of his childhood. The script was written in a semi-autobiographical style, with many of the events and characters drawn from Spielberg's own life.

### Pre-production

Pre-production on the film began in early 2021, with Spielberg assembling a team of long-time collaborators, including cinematographer Janusz Kaminski and production designer Adam Stockhausen.

### Casting

The casting process for the film was extensive, with Spielberg and his team searching for actors who could bring the characters to life. Gabriel LaBelle was cast as Sammy Fabelman after a lengthy audition process, while Michelle Williams and Paul Dano were brought on board to play Sammy's parents.

### Filming

Principal photography on the film began in July 2021 and lasted for several months. The film was shot on location in Arizona and California, with Spielberg using a combination of practical and digital effects to bring the world of the film to life.

### Production design

The production design for the film was handled by Adam Stockhausen, who worked closely with Spielberg to create a nostalgic and authentic look for the film. The film's sets and costumes were designed to evoke the look and feel of the 1950s and 1960s, with a particular emphasis on the Fabelman family's home and the local movie theater.

### Visual effects

The visual effects for the film were handled by a team of artists and technicians who worked to create a seamless blend of practical and digital effects. The film's visual effects were used to enhance the film's action sequences and to bring the world of the film to life.

Music
=====

The score for the film was composed by John Williams, who has collaborated with Spielberg on many of his films. The score is a nostalgic and emotive blend of jazz and classical music, with a particular emphasis on the piano.

Themes and interpretations
=========================

The Fabelmans is a film about the power of storytelling and the importance of family. The film explores themes of identity, creativity, and the complexities of family relationships. It is also a nostalgic tribute to the early days of cinema and the magic of the movies.

Release
=======

### Theatrical

The Fabelmans was released in theaters in November 2022, with a wide release in the United States and a limited release in other countries.

### Home media

The film was released on home media in February 2023, with a Blu-ray and DVD release.

### Marketing

The marketing campaign for the film was extensive, with a series of trailers and TV spots released in the months leading up to the film's release. The film's poster and social media campaign were also widely publicized.

Reception
==========

### Box office

The Fabelmans was a moderate box office success, grossing over $50 million worldwide.

### Critical response

The film received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's nostalgic charm and the performances of the cast. The film has a 92% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.1/10.

### Legacy

The Fabelmans is a film that is likely to be remembered for many years to come, with its nostalgic charm and its exploration of themes that are both personal and universal.

### Accolades

The film received several awards and nominations, including a Golden Globe nomination for Best Motion Picture - Drama.

Possible sequel
================

There has been speculation about a possible sequel to the film, although nothing has been officially announced.

article:
Barry Humphries
================

John Barry Humphries AO, CBE is a renowned Australian comedian, actor, and satirist, best known for his iconic characters Dame Edna Everage, Sir Les Patterson, and Sandy Stone. With a career spanning over six decades, Humphries has established himself as one of the most beloved and respected figures in the entertainment industry.

Early Life
-----------

Barry Humphries was born on February 17, 1934, in Kew, Melbourne, Australia. His father, Eric Humphries, was a construction manager, and his mother, Louisa, was a charity worker. Humphries was the second of three children, and his family moved frequently during his childhood due to his father's job.

Education
----------

Humphries attended Melbourne Grammar School and later studied at the University of Melbourne, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in philosophy. During his university days, Humphries developed an interest in the theatre and began performing in student revues.

Career
-------

### Early Career in Australia

Humphries began his career in the entertainment industry in the 1950s, performing in various revues and stage shows in Melbourne. In 1955, he joined the Melbourne Theatre Company, where he worked as an actor, writer, and director. During this period, Humphries developed his skills as a satirist and comedian, often incorporating his observations on Australian culture and society into his performances.

### London and the 1960s

In 1959, Humphries moved to London, where he became a key figure in the city's satirical scene. He performed at various clubs and venues, including the famous Establishment Club, and worked alongside other notable comedians, such as Peter Cook and Dudley Moore. During the 1960s, Humphries also began to develop his iconic character, Dame Edna Everage, a satirical take on the stereotypical Australian housewife.

### 1970s

The 1970s were a pivotal decade for Humphries, as he gained widespread recognition and acclaim for his work. He toured extensively with his one-man shows, including "A Night with Dame Edna" and "Housewife Superstar," and appeared on various television programs, including "The Morecambe and Wise Show" and "The Tonight Show." In 1974, Humphries was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) for his services to the arts.

### Film Roles

Humphries has appeared in numerous films throughout his career, including "Bedazzled" (1967), "The Bliss of Mrs. Blossom" (1968), and "The Great Waltz" (1972). In 1987, he played the role of Bruce, a campy and flamboyant interior designer, in the film "Les Patterson Saves the World."

### One-Man Shows

Humphries has written and performed numerous one-man shows throughout his career, often incorporating his iconic characters and satirical observations. Some notable shows include "Dame Edna: The Royal Tour" (1999), "Back with a Vengeance" (2003), and "Eat Pray Laugh!" (2009).

### Television Roles

Humphries has appeared on various television programs, including "The Muppet Show," "Saturday Night Live," and "The Simpsons." He has also hosted several television shows, including "The Dame Edna Experience" and "Dame Edna's Hollywood."

### Success in the United States

In the 1970s and 1980s, Humphries gained significant popularity in the United States, particularly with his iconic character, Dame Edna Everage. He toured extensively across the country and appeared on various television programs, including "The Tonight Show" and "Saturday Night Live."

### Farewell Tour

In 2012, Humphries announced his farewell tour, "Eat Pray Laugh!," which visited cities across Australia, the United States, and the United Kingdom. The tour marked the end of an era for Humphries, who had been performing for over six decades.

### Weimar Cabaret

In recent years, Humphries has been involved in various projects, including the Weimar Cabaret, a series of performances that pay tribute to the music and culture of 1920s and 1930s Germany. Humphries has worked alongside other notable performers, including Meow Meow and Amanda Palmer, to create a unique and captivating experience.

Characters
----------

### Dame Edna Everage

Dame Edna Everage is one of Humphries' most iconic and beloved characters. A satirical take on the stereotypical Australian housewife, Dame Edna is a flamboyant and charismatic figure, known for her sharp wit and outrageous humor. Dame Edna has been a central part of Humphries' career, and has appeared in numerous stage shows, films, and television programs.

### Sir Les Patterson

Sir Les Patterson is another iconic character created by Humphries. A boorish and irreverent Australian diplomat, Sir Les is a satirical take on the stereotypical Australian male. Sir Les has appeared in numerous stage shows and films, including "Les Patterson Saves the World" (1987).

### Sandy Stone

Sandy Stone is a lesser-known but equally fascinating character created by Humphries. A melancholic and introspective Australian, Sandy is a satirical take on the stereotypical Australian male. Sandy has appeared in numerous stage shows and films, including "A Night with Dame Edna" (1979).

Personal Life
------------

### Views on Transgenderism

In recent years, Humphries has faced controversy over his views on transgenderism. In a 2016 interview, Humphries stated that he was "appalled" by the idea of gender identity, sparking outrage from the LGBTQ+ community. Humphries later clarified his comments, stating that he was "deeply sorry" for any offense caused.

### Death

On April 22, 2023, Barry Humphries passed away at the age of 89, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most beloved and respected figures in the entertainment industry.

Other Work
----------

### Bibliography

Humphries has written several books throughout his career, including "A Nice Cup of Tea and a Sit Down" (1973) and "My Life as Me" (2002).

### Filmography

Humphries has appeared in numerous films throughout his career, including "Bedazzled" (1967), "The Bliss of Mrs. Blossom" (1968), and "Les Patterson Saves the World" (1987).

### Discography

Humphries has released several albums throughout his career, including "Dame Edna's Greatest Hits" (1979) and "Les Patterson's Greatest Hits" (1987).

### Biographical Studies

Several biographical studies have been written about Humphries, including "Barry Humphries: The Authorized Biography" (2002) and "The Man Behind the Dame" (2014).

### Fictional Characters

Awards and Honours

article:
RRR is a 2022 Indian Telugu-language period action drama film written and directed by S. S. Rajamouli. Produced by D. V. V. Danayya of DVV Entertainments, the film stars N. T. Rama Rao Jr., Ram Charan, Alia Bhatt, and Olivia Morris. Set in the 1920s, RRR is a fictional story based on the lives of two Indian revolutionaries, Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem, who fought against the British Raj.

# Plot

RRR is set in the 1920s and revolves around the lives of two Indian revolutionaries, Alluri Sitarama Raju (played by Ram Charan) and Komaram Bheem (played by N. T. Rama Rao Jr.). The film's story is a fictional account of their lives, showcasing their struggles, friendships, and fight against the British Raj. The story begins with the introduction of Komaram Bheem, a Gond tribal leader who is fighting against the British colonialists in the forests of Adilabad. Meanwhile, Alluri Sitarama Raju, a police officer, is tasked with capturing Bheem. However, their paths cross, and they become friends, leading to a series of events that change the course of their lives.

# Cast

The film features an ensemble cast, including:

* N. T. Rama Rao Jr. as Komaram Bheem
* Ram Charan as Alluri Sitarama Raju
* Alia Bhatt as Sita
* Olivia Morris as Jennifer
* Ajay Devgn as Venkata Rama Raju
* Shriya Saran as Sarojini
* Samuthirakani as Venkateswarulu
* Rahul Ramakrishna as Lachu
* Ray Stevenson as Governor Scott Buxton
* Alison Doody as Lady Buxton

# Production

## Development

RRR was conceptualized by S. S. Rajamouli in 2012, after the release of his film Eega. However, the project was put on hold due to various reasons, including the director's commitment to the Baahubali franchise. In 2018, Rajamouli announced that he would be working on a new project, which was later revealed to be RRR. The film's script was written by Rajamouli and his father, K. V. Vijayendra Prasad.

## Casting

The casting process for RRR began in 2018, with N. T. Rama Rao Jr. and Ram Charan being the first actors to be cast. Alia Bhatt and Olivia Morris were later cast in pivotal roles. The film also features a number of supporting actors, including Ajay Devgn, Shriya Saran, and Samuthirakani.

## Design

The film's production design was handled by Sabu Cyril, who created elaborate sets to recreate the 1920s era. The costumes were designed by Rama Rajamouli, who worked closely with the actors to create authentic period costumes.

## Principal photography

The principal photography of RRR began in November 2018 and lasted for over two years. The film was shot in various locations, including Hyderabad, Rajahmundry, and Gujarat. The film's cinematography was handled by K. K. Senthil Kumar, who used a combination of digital and film cameras to capture the film's visuals.

## Post-production

The post-production of RRR began in 2020, with the film's editor, A. Sreekar Prasad, working closely with Rajamouli to create the final cut. The film's music was composed by M. M. Keeravani, who created a mix of period-specific and contemporary tracks.

# Themes and influences

RRR is a period action drama that explores themes of friendship, loyalty, and rebellion. The film is influenced by the lives of Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem, who fought against the British Raj. The film also draws inspiration from Indian mythology and folklore, with Rajamouli incorporating various mythological references into the story.

# Music

The film's music was composed by M. M. Keeravani, who created a mix of period-specific and contemporary tracks. The soundtrack features a number of songs, including "Dosti," "Naatu Naatu," and "Janani." The film's background score was also composed by Keeravani, who worked closely with Rajamouli to create an immersive audio experience.

# Marketing

The marketing campaign for RRR began in 2020, with the film's trailer being released in March 2021. The film's promotional campaign included a number of innovative strategies, including the use of augmented reality and social media influencers.

# Release

## Theatrical

RRR was released theatrically on March 25, 2022, in Telugu, Tamil, Hindi, Kannada, and Malayalam. The film received a wide release, with over 10,000 screens being allocated for the film worldwide.

## Screenings and statistics

RRR opened to positive reviews from critics and audiences alike, with the film grossing over ₹150 crore on its opening day. The film went on to gross over ₹1,000 crore worldwide, becoming one of the highest-grossing Indian films of all time.

## Distribution

The film's distribution rights were acquired by various distributors, including Pen India Limited, Lyca Productions, and KVN Productions.

## Home media

RRR was released on digital platforms, including Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, and Disney+ Hotstar, on May 20, 2022.

# Critical reception

## India

RRR received widespread critical acclaim in India, with many critics praising the film's visuals, music, and performances. The film holds a 91% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 50 reviews.

## International

RRR also received positive reviews from international critics, with many praising the film's action sequences, music, and cultural significance. The film holds a 82% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on over 20 reviews.

# Reception by international filmmakers

RRR has been praised by various international filmmakers, including James Gunn, Scott Derrickson, and Guillermo del Toro. The film's action sequences and visuals have been widely praised, with many considering it one of the best action films of 2022.

# Box office

RRR was a major commercial success, grossing over ₹1,000 crore worldwide. The film became one of the highest-grossing Indian films of all time, surpassing films like Baahubali 2 and Dangal.

# Impact

RRR has had a significant impact on Indian cinema, with many considering it a game-changer for the industry. The film's success has paved the way for more Indian films to be released globally, with many filmmakers looking to replicate its success.

# Accolades

RRR has won numerous awards, including the National Film Award for Best Stunt Direction, the Filmfare Award for Best Action, and the IIFA Award for Best Action.

# Adaptations

There have been reports of RRR being adapted into a Hollywood film, with various studios and production companies showing interest in acquiring the rights.

# Future

RRR is set to be followed by a sequel, which is currently in development. The film's director, S. S. Rajamouli, has announced that he will be working on a new project, which is expected to be released in 2025.

UAAP Season 85 Volleyball Tournaments
=====================================

The UAAP Season 85 volleyball tournaments, also known as the UAAP Volleyball Season 85, is the 85th season of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP) volleyball tournaments. The tournaments are divided into four divisions: men's, women's, boys', and girls'. The season began on October 15, 2022, and concluded on December 17, 2022.

Tournament Format
-----------------

The tournament format for the UAAP Season 85 volleyball tournaments is as follows:

* Double-round robin eliminations for the men's and women's divisions
* Single-round robin eliminations for the boys' and girls' divisions

* Semifinals and finals are played in a best-of-three format

Leonardo Torres Quevedo
=====================

Leonardo Torres Quevedo was a Spanish engineer, mathematician, and inventor, best known for his pioneering work in the development of automation, analogue computing, and robotics. His innovative ideas and inventions had a significant impact on the fields of engineering, mathematics, and computer science, and he is considered one of the most important Spanish scientists of the 20th century.

Early life and education
------------------------

Leonardo Torres Quevedo was born on December 28, 1852, in Santa Cruz de Iber, a small village in the province of Santander, Spain. He was the eldest of six children born to a family of modest means. His parents, both of whom were teachers, encouraged his interest in mathematics and science from an early age.

Torres Quevedo attended the Colegio de la Inmaculada in Santander, where he developed a strong foundation in mathematics and physics. In 1870, he moved to Madrid to study civil engineering at the Escuela de Ingenieros de Caminos, Canales y Puertos. He graduated in 1876 and began working as a civil engineer on various projects in Spain.

Career
--------

Torres Quevedo's career spanned over five decades and was marked by numerous innovations and inventions. His work can be broadly categorized into several areas, including cableways, analogue calculating machines, aerostatics, radio control, formal language, laboratory of automation, chess automaton, essays on automatics, naval projects, and other inventions.

### Cableways

In the late 1880s, Torres Quevedo began working on the development of cableways, a system of overhead cables used for transporting materials and people. He designed and built several cableway systems in Spain and abroad, including the famous cableway in the Niagara Falls.

### Analogue calculating machines

Torres Quevedo is credited with inventing the first electromechanical analogue calculating machine, which he called the "aritmómetro." This machine was capable of performing basic arithmetic operations and was the precursor to modern computers.

### Aerostatics

In the early 1900s, Torres Quevedo turned his attention to aerostatics, the study of the behavior of gases in equilibrium. He invented a device called the "aerostatic integrator," which was used to calculate the area under curves.

### Radio control: the Telekino

In 1903, Torres Quevedo invented the Telekino, a radio-controlled boat that was the precursor to modern remote-control devices. The Telekino was the first device to use radio waves to control the movement of an object.

### Formal language

Torres Quevedo was also interested in formal language and developed a system of notation for mathematical logic. His work in this area predated the development of modern computer programming languages.

### Laboratory of Automation

In 1912, Torres Quevedo established the Laboratory of Automation in Madrid, which was dedicated to the development of automation and robotics. The laboratory became a hub for innovation and experimentation, and Torres Quevedo and his team developed numerous inventions and machines.

### Chess automaton: El Ajedrecista

In 1912, Torres Quevedo built a chess automaton called El Ajedrecista, which was capable of playing chess against a human opponent. El Ajedrecista was the first chess-playing machine in the world and was a significant innovation in the field of artificial intelligence.

### Essays on Automatics

Torres Quevedo wrote several essays on automatics, including "Essays on Automatics," which was published in 1914. In this book, he outlined his vision for a future where machines would be able to perform tasks autonomously.

#### Analytical machines

Torres Quevedo was also interested in analytical machines, which were capable of performing complex calculations. He developed several analytical machines, including the "calculating machine," which was capable of performing arithmetic operations.

### Naval projects

Torres Quevedo worked on several naval projects, including the development of a submarine that could be controlled remotely. He also designed a system for launching torpedoes from submarines.

### Other inventions and miscellaneous activities

Torres Quevedo was a prolific inventor and developed numerous other inventions and machines, including a machine for making cigarettes, a machine for sorting mail, and a machine for making shoes.

#### Esperantist

Torres Quevedo was also an Esperantist and believed in the importance of a universal language. He was a member of the Esperanto movement and wrote several articles on the subject.

#### Spanish-American Technological Dictionary

Torres Quevedo edited the Spanish-American Technological Dictionary, which was a comprehensive dictionary of technical terms used in engineering and technology.

Distinctions
------------

Torres Quevedo received numerous distinctions and awards for his work, including the Grand Cross of the Order of Alfonso XII and the Grand Cross of the Order of Isabel la Católica.

Personal life, religious beliefs and death
-----------------------------------------

Torres Quevedo was a devout Catholic and believed in the importance of faith and reason. He was married to Doña Sofía Bühler and had five children. He died on December 18, 1936, at the age of 83, in Madrid, Spain.

Legacy
--------

Torres Quevedo's legacy is immense, and his work had a significant impact on the development of automation, analogue computing, and robotics. He is considered one of the most important Spanish scientists of the 20th century, and his inventions and machines are still studied and admired today.

In fiction
----------

Torres Quevedo has been the subject of several works of fiction, including a novel by the Spanish writer, Miguel de Unamuno.

article:
Aryan Valley
================

The Aryan Valley is a remote and isolated valley located in the Ladakh region of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. It is a unique and fascinating area that has drawn the attention of anthropologists, historians, and adventurers alike. The valley is home to the Brokpa people, an indigenous community that has maintained their distinct culture and traditions despite being surrounded by the influences of the outside world.

Geography and Economy
---------------------

The Aryan Valley is situated in the Kargil district of Ladakh, approximately 160 kilometers (100 miles) east of the town of Kargil. The valley is nestled in the Himalayas, surrounded by towering mountains that rise to an altitude of over 6,000 meters (20,000 feet). The valley itself is at an elevation of around 3,500 meters (11,500 feet) above sea level.

The valley is relatively small, stretching for about 30 kilometers (19 miles) in length and 10 kilometers (6 miles) in width. The terrain is rugged, with steep cliffs and rocky outcrops, and the soil is thin and infertile. Despite these challenges, the Brokpa people have developed a unique system of agriculture that allows them to cultivate the land and raise livestock.

The economy of the Aryan Valley is primarily based on subsistence farming and animal husbandry. The Brokpa people grow crops such as barley, wheat, and potatoes, and raise animals such as yaks, goats, and sheep. The valley is also rich in mineral resources, including copper, zinc, and lead, which have been mined in the past.

History
--------

The history of the Aryan Valley is shrouded in mystery, and there is much debate about the origins of the Brokpa people. However, it is believed that the valley has been inhabited for thousands of years, with archaeological evidence suggesting that humans were present in the area as far back as the Neolithic period.

### Brokpas

The Brokpa people are an indigenous community that has lived in the Aryan Valley for centuries. They are believed to be descended from the ancient Aryans, who migrated to the Indian subcontinent from Central Asia around 1500 BCE. The Brokpa people have maintained their distinct culture and traditions, despite being surrounded by the influences of the outside world.

The Brokpa people are known for their unique customs and practices, which are influenced by their Buddhist and animist traditions. They are skilled farmers and herders, and have developed a deep understanding of the natural world. The Brokpa people are also known for their expertise in medicine, and have developed a range of treatments using local herbs and plants.

### Aryan Association and Neologism

The term "Aryan" has become associated with the valley and its people, due to the valley's name and the supposed origins of the Brokpa people. However, this term is also associated with the Indo-Aryan migration theory, which suggests that the Indian subcontinent was invaded by Indo-European speakers from Central Asia around 1500 BCE.

This theory has been widely criticized, and many scholars argue that the term "Aryan" is a neologism that has been imposed on the Brokpa people by outsiders. The Brokpa people themselves do not identify as "Aryans", and instead refer to themselves as "Brokpa" or "Minaro".

article:
Eiji Tsuburaya

Eiji Tsuburaya was a Japanese special effects director, filmmaker, and entrepreneur, best known for his work on the Godzilla franchise and the Ultraman television series. Born on July 7, 1901, in Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan, Tsuburaya would go on to become one of the most influential figures in Japanese science fiction and fantasy cinema.

# Biography

## Childhood to war years: 1901–1945

### Childhood and youth (1901–1919)

Eiji Tsuburaya was born to a family of modest means in Sukagawa, Fukushima, Japan. His early life was marked by a strong interest in science and technology, which would later influence his work in special effects. Tsuburaya attended the Tokyo Institute of Technology, where he studied mechanical engineering and developed skills that would serve him well in his future career.

### Early career and marriage (1919–1934)

After completing his studies, Tsuburaya worked as a mechanic and engineer before entering the film industry in the early 1920s. He began his career as a cinematographer and later became a special effects technician, working on several Japanese films during the 1920s and 1930s. In 1926, Tsuburaya married his wife, Masano, with whom he would have two children.

### J.O. Studios, directorial works, and Toho (1934–1940)

In 1934, Tsuburaya joined J.O. Studios, where he worked as a special effects director on several films, including the 1936 production of "The New Earth." During this period, he also began to develop his skills as a director, working on several films and shorts. In 1937, Tsuburaya joined Toho Studios, where he would spend much of his career and work on some of his most famous projects.

### War years (1941–1945)

During World War II, Tsuburaya continued to work in the film industry, producing propaganda and training films for the Japanese military. He also worked on several feature films, including the 1942 production of "The War at Sea from Hawaii to Malay." Tsuburaya's experiences during the war had a profound impact on his later work, particularly in his depiction of destruction and chaos in his science fiction films.

## Occupation years to Chūshingura: 1946–1962

### Early postwar work (1946–1954)

Following Japan's defeat in World War II, Tsuburaya continued to work in the film industry, producing a number of films and shorts during the occupation period. In 1949, he rejoined Toho Studios, where he would work on several key projects, including the 1951 production of "The Tale of the White Serpent."

### International recognition (1954–1959)

Tsuburaya's breakthrough as a special effects director came with the 1954 production of "Godzilla," which became a huge success in Japan and internationally. The film's success led to a series of sequels and spin-offs, cementing Tsuburaya's reputation as a master of science fiction and fantasy cinema.

### From The Secret of the Telegian to Chūshingura (1960–1962)

During the early 1960s, Tsuburaya continued to work on a number of science fiction and fantasy films, including "The Secret of the Telegian" (1960) and "The Last War" (1961). In 1962, he directed the historical epic "Chūshingura," which became a major success in Japan and marked a turning point in his career.

## Birth of a company to last years: 1963–1970

### Birth of a company and career expansion (1963–1964)

In 1963, Tsuburaya founded his own production company, Tsuburaya Productions, which would go on to produce a number of science fiction and fantasy films and television shows. The company's first major success came with the 1963 production of "Ultraman," a television series that became a huge hit in Japan and internationally.

### Japanese-American coproductions and Ultra Q (1964–1965)

During the mid-1960s, Tsuburaya Productions began to produce a number of Japanese-American coproductions, including the 1964 television series "Ultra Q." The series was a major success in Japan and the United States, and marked a new era in international cooperation in science fiction and fantasy television.

### Ultraman and beyond (1966–1967)

In 1966, Tsuburaya Productions produced the second season of "Ultraman," which became an even bigger success than the first season. The series' success led to a number of spin-offs and sequels, cementing Tsuburaya's reputation as a master of science fiction and fantasy television.

### Final works, last years, and death (1968–1970)

During his final years, Tsuburaya continued to work on a number of science fiction and fantasy films and television shows, including the 1969 production of "Destroy All Monsters." Tsuburaya passed away on January 25, 1970, at the age of 68, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most influential figures in Japanese science fiction and fantasy cinema.

# Filmmaking

## Style, themes, and techniques

Tsuburaya's filmmaking style was characterized by his use of practical special effects, which gave his films a sense of realism and authenticity. He was also known for his innovative use of miniature models and matte paintings, which allowed him to create elaborate and detailed sets.

Tsuburaya's films often explored themes of science, technology, and the human condition, and he was particularly interested in the consequences of scientific progress and technological advancement. His films often featured monsters, aliens, and other supernatural creatures, which served as metaphors for the fears and anxieties of modern society.

## Relationship with cast and crew

Tsuburaya was known for his collaborative approach to filmmaking, and he worked closely with his cast and crew to develop his ideas and bring his vision to life. He was particularly close to his special effects team, which included many talented technicians and artists who worked with him throughout his career.

## Production and editing

Tsuburaya was a meticulous and detail-oriented filmmaker, and he was heavily involved in all aspects of production and editing. He worked closely with his editors to develop the pacing and tone of his films, and he was known for his innovative use of camera angles and composition.

# Legacy

## Cultural impact

Tsuburaya's films and television shows have had a profound impact on popular culture, and he is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in Japanese science fiction and fantasy cinema. His films have been referenced and homaged in countless other works, and he continues to inspire new generations of filmmakers and special effects artists.

## Tributes

Tsuburaya has been the subject of numerous tributes and retrospectives, including a 2011 retrospective at the Tokyo International Film Festival. He has also been honored with numerous awards and accolades, including a posthumous award for lifetime achievement from the Japanese Academy of Film.

## Portrayals

Tsuburaya has been portrayed in several films and television shows, including the 2014 Japanese film "The Man Who Defied the Monster," which tells the story of his life and career.

# Selected filmography

2022 United States Senate election in Georgia

The 2022 United States Senate election in Georgia was held on November 8, 2022, to elect a member of the United States Senate to represent the state of Georgia. The election was won by incumbent Democratic Senator Raphael Warnock, who defeated Republican challenger Herschel Walker in a runoff election held on December 6, 2022.

#Democratic primary

The Democratic primary election was held on May 24, 2022.

##Candidates

###Nominee

Raphael Warnock, incumbent U.S. Senator

Warnock, the senior pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, was first elected to the Senate in a 2020 special election. He ran for a full six-year term in 2022.

###Eliminated in primary

Tamara Johnson-Shealey, Smyrna City Councilwoman

Johnson-Shealey, a member of the Smyrna City Council, ran for the Democratic nomination but lost to Warnock.

##Endorsements

Warnock was endorsed by several prominent Democrats, including President Joe Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris, and former President Barack Obama.

##Polling

Warnock led Johnson-Shealey by a wide margin in pre-primary polls.

##Results

Warnock won the primary election with 96% of the vote, defeating Johnson-Shealey.

#Republican primary

The Republican primary election was held on May 24, 2022.

##Candidates

###Nominee

Herschel Walker, former NFL player and businessman

Walker, a former University of Georgia football player and NFL running back, was endorsed by former President Donald Trump. He won the Republican nomination with 68% of the vote.

###Eliminated in primary

Gary Black, Georgia Agriculture Commissioner

Black, the incumbent Agriculture Commissioner, ran for the Republican nomination but lost to Walker.

Latham Saddler, businessman and former Navy SEAL

Saddler, a businessman and former Navy SEAL, also ran for the Republican nomination but lost to Walker.

Kelvin King, pastor and businessman

King, a pastor and businessman, ran for the Republican nomination but lost to Walker.

Josh Clark, businessman

Clark, a businessman, also ran for the Republican nomination but lost to Walker.

###Declined

Kelly Loeffler, former U.S. Senator

Loeffler, who lost to Warnock in the 2020 special election, declined to run for the Republican nomination.

Doug Collins, former U.S. Representative

Collins, a former U.S. Representative, also declined to run for the Republican nomination.

##Debates

The Republican candidates participated in several debates, including one hosted by the Atlanta Press Club.

##Endorsements

Walker was endorsed by former President Donald Trump, while Black was endorsed by several Republican state legislators.

##Polling

Walker led the Republican field in pre-primary polls.

##Results

Walker won the primary election with 68% of the vote, defeating Black, Saddler, King, and Clark.

#Libertarian primary

The Libertarian primary election was held on May 24, 2022.

##Candidates

###Declared

Chase Oliver, Libertarian nominee

Oliver, a Libertarian activist, won the Libertarian nomination unopposed.

#General election

article:
Embassy without a government
==========================

An embassy without a government is a diplomatic mission that continues to operate and represent the interests of a country or a people despite the absence of a functioning government or a recognized authority. This phenomenon has occurred throughout history, often as a result of war, revolution, or occupation. In this article, we will explore four notable examples of embassies without governments: Russia (1917–1925), Spain (1939–1977), Poland (1939–1990), and Afghanistan (2021–present).

History
-------

### Russia (1917–1925)

#### Diplomatic missions after 1917

Following the Russian Revolution of 1917, the Bolsheviks seized power, and the Russian Empire was dissolved. The Soviet government, led by Vladimir Lenin, initially maintained diplomatic relations with other countries, but these relations were soon severed due to the Soviet Union's radical policies and the subsequent Russian Civil War. Despite the absence of a recognized government, Russian diplomatic missions abroad continued to operate, often in a state of limbo.

Many Russian diplomats remained loyal to the deposed Romanov dynasty or the anti-Bolshevik White movement, while others sympathized with the Soviet government. This led to a complex situation, with multiple rival diplomatic missions claiming to represent Russia. The most notable example was the Russian Embassy in Paris, which continued to operate under the auspices of the former imperial government.

#### Dissolution of the Soviet Union

In 1925, the Soviet Union officially recognized the Russian Empire's pre-revolutionary debts and established diplomatic relations with France, marking the beginning of the end of the Russian Embassy without a government. The embassy was eventually dissolved, and its functions were transferred to the Soviet diplomatic mission.

### Spain (1939–1977)

#### Diplomatic missions after 1939

The Spanish Civil War (1936–1939) ended with the victory of the Nationalist forces led by General Francisco Franco, who established a fascist dictatorship. The Republican government, which had been recognized by the international community, was forced into exile. Despite the absence of a recognized government, many Spanish diplomatic missions abroad continued to operate, often with the support of local authorities.

The Spanish Embassy in Mexico, for example, remained loyal to the Republican government and continued to issue passports and provide consular services to Spanish citizens. This led to a situation where there were two rival Spanish diplomatic missions: the official Francoist mission and the Republican mission in exile.

### Poland (1939–1990)

#### Diplomatic missions after 1939

During World War II, Poland was invaded and occupied by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. The Polish government-in-exile, led by President Władysław Raczkiewicz, established diplomatic relations with the Allied powers and maintained a network of diplomatic missions abroad.

Despite the establishment of a communist government in Poland after the war, many Polish diplomatic missions continued to operate under the auspices of the government-in-exile. The Polish Embassy in London, for example, remained a focal point for the Polish diaspora and continued to issue passports and provide consular services.

### Afghanistan (2021–present)

#### Diplomatic missions after 2021

In August 2021, the Taliban seized power in Afghanistan, leading to the collapse of the internationally recognized government. Many Afghan diplomatic missions abroad continued to operate, often with the support of local authorities.

The Afghan Embassy in Washington, D.C., for example, remained open and continued to provide consular services to Afghan citizens. However, the embassy's status remains uncertain, as the Taliban government has not been recognized by the international community.

* Recognition of states

This article is a factual account of the phenomenon of embassies without governments. The examples provided are intended to illustrate the complexities and challenges that arise when diplomatic missions continue to operate despite the absence of a recognized government or authority.

The 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification is an international football competition which will be held in 2023 to determine the participating teams for the 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup. A total of 16 teams will qualify to play in the final tournament, including Uzbekistan who qualified automatically as hosts.

Format changes

The format of the qualification process has been changed from previous editions. Instead of a two-round qualification process, the 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification will feature a single round of group stage matches, followed by a ranking of the runners-up to determine the remaining spots in the final tournament.

article:
2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup

The 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup was the 23rd edition of the FIFA U-20 World Cup, the biennial international men's youth football championship contested by the under-20 national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The tournament was originally scheduled to take place in Indonesia from 10 May to 11 June 2023, but due to protests and logistical issues, FIFA announced on 29 March 2023 that the tournament would be moved to Argentina.

#Host selection

The bidding process for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup began in 2019, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament. On 24 October 2019, FIFA announced that Indonesia had been selected as the host nation, beating out bids from Brazil, Peru, and Uzbekistan. However, in March 2023, FIFA announced that Indonesia would no longer host the tournament due to protests and logistical issues, and on 29 March 2023, Argentina was announced as the new host nation.

#Qualified teams

A total of 24 teams qualified for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup. The host nation, Argentina, qualified automatically, while the remaining 23 teams qualified through various continental competitions. The qualified teams were:

* Asia: 4 teams (Iraq, Japan, South Korea, Uzbekistan)
* Africa: 4 teams (Egypt, Gambia, Nigeria, Senegal)
* North and Central America and the Caribbean: 4 teams (Canada, Dominican Republic, Honduras, United States)
* South America: 6 teams (Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Uruguay)
* Europe: 6 teams (England, France, Israel, Italy, Slovakia, Ukraine)
* Oceania: 1 team (Fiji)

#Venues

The tournament was held across six venues in Argentina. The venues were:

* Estadio Monumental Antonio Vespucio Liberti in Buenos Aires
* Estadio Alberto J. Armando in Buenos Aires
* Estadio Ciudad de La Plata in La Plata
* Estadio Centenario in Resistencia
* Estadio Padre Ernesto Martearena in Salta
* Estadio Único Madre de Ciudades in Santiago del Estero

#Draw

The draw for the tournament took place on 29 March 2023, with the 24 teams drawn into six groups of four teams each. The draw was conducted by former Argentina international Diego Maradona and FIFA Secretary-General Fatma Samoura.

#Match officials

A total of 17 referees and 30 assistant referees were appointed for the tournament. The referees were:

* Asia: 4 referees (Ahmad Al-Ali, Ahmed Al-Kaf, Abdulrahman Al-Jassim, Ryuji Sato)
* Africa: 4 referees (Amin Omar, Mustapha Ghorbal, Jean Jacques Ndala Ngambo, Redouane Jiyed)
* North and Central America and the Caribbean: 3 referees (Oshane Nation, César Ramos, Said Martínez)
* South America: 4 referees (Jesús Valenzuela, Wilton Sampaio, Andrés Matonte, Alexis Herrera)
* Europe: 4 referees (István Kovács, François Letexier, Georgi Kabakov, Donatas Rumšas)
* Oceania: 1 referee (Campbell-Kirk Waugh)

#Squads

Each team was required to submit a squad of 21 players, three of whom must be goalkeepers. The squads were announced on 10 May 2023.

#Group stage

The group stage took place from 20 May to 31 May 2023. The teams were divided into six groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group and the four best third-placed teams advancing to the knockout stage.

##Tiebreakers

In the event of two or more teams being level on points, the following tiebreakers were used:

* Goal difference in all group matches
* Number of goals scored in all group matches
* Number of points obtained in matches between the tied teams
* Goal difference in matches between the tied teams
* Number of goals scored in matches between the tied teams
* Drawing of lots

* Number of goals scored in all group matches
* Drawing of lots

#Knockout stage

The knockout stage took place from 3 June to 11 June 2023. The teams were divided into a single-elimination bracket, with the winners advancing to the next round and the losers being eliminated.

article:
FTX

FTX is a cryptocurrency derivatives exchange that was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried and Gary Wang. The exchange gained popularity due to its innovative products, such as perpetual swaps and options, and its user-friendly interface. FTX was headquartered in the Bahamas and was known for its high liquidity and low fees. However, in November 2022, the exchange faced a severe crisis that led to its bankruptcy and had far-reaching consequences for the cryptocurrency market.

# History

FTX was founded in April 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried, a former trader at Jane Street, and Gary Wang, a former Google engineer. The exchange was initially based in Hong Kong but later moved to the Bahamas. FTX quickly gained popularity due to its innovative products, such as perpetual swaps and options, and its user-friendly interface. The exchange also introduced a token called FTT, which was used to facilitate transactions and provide discounts to users.

In 2020, FTX raised $8 million in funding from investors, including Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange. The funding round was led by Binance Labs, the venture arm of Binance. FTX used the funding to expand its operations and develop new products.

In 2021, FTX raised an additional $900 million in funding from investors, including Sequoia Capital, SoftBank, and Ribbit Capital. The funding round valued FTX at $18 billion, making it one of the most valuable cryptocurrency companies in the world.

2022–23 European windstorm season

The 2022–23 European windstorm season was the sixth instance of seasonal European windstorm naming. The season started on September 1, 2022, and will end on August 31, 2023. This season's storms caused significant disruptions and damage across Europe, resulting in numerous fatalities and economic losses.

Background and naming

The European windstorm season is a period of increased storm activity that affects Europe during the autumn and winter months. This season's storms are fueled by the contrast in temperature between the cold polar air and the warmer air from the equator. The naming of storms is a collaborative effort between various European meteorological agencies to raise awareness and facilitate communication about severe weather events.

Definitions and naming conventions

The European windstorm season is defined as the period between September 1 and August 31 of the following year. Storms are named when they are expected to bring strong winds, heavy rainfall, or other severe weather conditions that may impact daily life. The naming of storms is based on a predetermined list of names that are assigned alphabetically. The list of names is rotated annually, with the exception of names that are retired due to the severity of the damage caused by the storm.

Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland and the Netherlands)

The Western Group consists of the United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands. This region is prone to strong westerly winds that can bring severe weather conditions. Storms that affect this region are named by the UK Met Office, Met Éireann, and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI).

South-western Group (France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Luxembourg)

The South-western Group consists of France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. This region is susceptible to storms that develop in the Atlantic and move eastwards. Storms that affect this region are named by Météo-France, the Spanish State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the Portuguese Institute for Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA), the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium (RMI), and the Luxembourg National Meteorological Service (MétéoLux).

Southeastern Mediterranean Group (Greece, Israel and Cyprus)

The Southeastern Mediterranean Group consists of Greece, Israel, and Cyprus. This region is prone to storms that develop in the Mediterranean and move eastwards. Storms that affect this region are named by the Hellenic National Meteorological Service (HNMS), the Israeli Meteorological Service (IMS), and the Cyprus Department of Meteorology (CDM).

Central Mediterranean Group (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Malta)

Northern Group (Denmark, Norway and Sweden)

Storms that affect this region are named by the Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI), the Norwegian Meteorological Institute (MET Norway), and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI).

Ex-Atlantic hurricanes are storms that have developed in the Atlantic and moved eastwards, bringing severe weather conditions to Europe. These storms are named by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) and are assigned a new name when they reach Europe.

article:
2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was a period of tropical cyclone formation in the South-West Indian Ocean, which occurred from July 2022 to June 2023. The season was characterized by the formation of several intense tropical cyclones, including two very intense tropical cyclones.

# Seasonal forecasts

Prior to the start of the season, the Mauritius Meteorological Services (MMS) and the Southwest Indian Ocean Tropical Cyclone Committee (SWIOTC) issued their seasonal forecasts. The MMS forecast predicted a near-average season with 9-12 named storms, while the SWIOTC forecast predicted a slightly above-average season with 10-14 named storms.

# Seasonal summary

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was an active season, with a total of 12 named storms forming during the period. The season was marked by the formation of several intense tropical cyclones, including two very intense tropical cyclones, Darian and Freddy. The season also saw the formation of several moderate tropical storms, including Ashley and Balita.

## Systems

### Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley

Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley formed on September 26, 2022, approximately 500 km (310 mi) east of Réunion. The system slowly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on September 29, with maximum sustained winds of 85 km/h (53 mph). Ashley dissipated on October 2, without making landfall.

### Moderate Tropical Storm Balita

Moderate Tropical Storm Balita formed on October 14, 2022, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system rapidly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on October 16, with maximum sustained winds of 95 km/h (59 mph). Balita dissipated on October 19, without making landfall.

### Tropical Depression 03

Tropical Depression 03 formed on November 22, 2022, approximately 500 km (310 mi) east of Mozambique. The system slowly intensified, but failed to reach tropical storm strength, dissipating on November 25.

### Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on December 20, 2022, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system rapidly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on December 24, with maximum sustained winds of 230 km/h (143 mph). Darian dissipated on January 2, 2023, without making landfall.

### Tropical Cyclone Cheneso

Tropical Cyclone Cheneso formed on January 18, 2023, approximately 500 km (310 mi) east of Réunion. The system slowly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on January 20, with maximum sustained winds of 120 km/h (75 mph). Cheneso made landfall in Madagascar on January 22, causing significant damage and flooding.

### Tropical Cyclone Dingani

Tropical Cyclone Dingani formed on February 9, 2023, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system slowly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on February 12, with maximum sustained winds of 140 km/h (87 mph). Dingani dissipated on February 16, without making landfall.

### Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on February 5, 2023, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system rapidly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on February 18, with maximum sustained winds of 240 km/h (150 mph). Freddy dissipated on March 14, 2023, after making landfall in Mozambique, causing significant damage and flooding.

### Tropical Cyclone Enala

Tropical Cyclone Enala formed on March 18, 2023, approximately 500 km (310 mi) east of Réunion. The system slowly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on March 20, with maximum sustained winds of 110 km/h (68 mph). Enala dissipated on March 23, without making landfall.

### Moderate Tropical Storm 09

Moderate Tropical Storm 09 formed on April 1, 2023, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system slowly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on April 3, with maximum sustained winds of 90 km/h (56 mph). The storm dissipated on April 6, without making landfall.

### Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien

Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien formed on May 10, 2023, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) west of the Seychelles. The system rapidly intensified, reaching its peak intensity on May 13, with maximum sustained winds of 200 km/h (124 mph). Fabien dissipated on May 19, without making landfall.

# Storm names

The Southwest Indian Ocean Tropical Cyclone Committee (SWIOTC) is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the South-West Indian Ocean. The names are assigned in alphabetical order, and are chosen from a list of names submitted by member countries.

# Season effects

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season had significant effects on several countries in the region, including Madagascar, Mozambique, and Réunion. The season saw the formation of several intense tropical cyclones, which caused significant damage and flooding in affected areas.
