article:
Ronald Reagan

Ronald Wilson Reagan was the 40th President of the United States, serving from 1981 to 1989. Prior to his presidency, he was an actor and the 33rd Governor of California from 1967 to 1975.

#Early life

Ronald Reagan was born on February 6, 1911, in Tampico, Illinois, to John Edward Reagan and Nelle Clyde Wilson Reagan. He had an older brother, Neil Reagan. The family moved frequently during Reagan's childhood, eventually settling in Dixon, Illinois. Reagan's father was a salesman and a fervent supporter of the Democratic Party. Reagan's mother was a homemaker and a devout Christian.

Reagan attended Eureka College in Illinois, where he studied economics and sociology. He was an active member of the college's drama club and played football. After graduating in 1932, Reagan moved to Iowa to work as a sports announcer for a local radio station.

#Entertainment career

##Radio and film

Reagan's early career in entertainment began in radio, where he worked as a sports announcer for various stations in the Midwest. In 1937, he moved to California to pursue a career in film. He signed a contract with Warner Bros. and began appearing in small roles in films and television shows. Reagan's breakthrough role came in 1940 with the film "Knute Rockne, All American," in which he played the role of George Gipp.

##Military service

During World War II, Reagan enlisted in the United States Army Reserve and was assigned to the Army Air Forces. He was classified for limited duty due to his nearsightedness and was assigned to the First Motion Picture Unit, where he produced training films and propaganda.

##Screen Actors Guild presidency

Reagan was an active member of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and served as its president from 1947 to 1952 and again from 1959 to 1960. During his tenure, he helped to negotiate better wages and working conditions for actors.

##Marriages and children

Reagan married Jane Wyman in 1940, and they had two children together, Maureen and Michael. The couple divorced in 1948. In 1952, Reagan married Nancy Davis, with whom he had two children, Patricia and Ronald Jr.

##Television

Reagan's career in television began in the 1950s, when he hosted various game shows and anthology series. He also appeared in numerous television films and series, including "General Electric Theater" and "Death Valley Days."

#Early political activities

##1966 California gubernatorial election

Reagan's entry into politics began in 1966, when he ran for Governor of California. He won the Republican primary and went on to defeat incumbent Governor Pat Brown in the general election.

#California governorship (1967–1975)

Reagan served as Governor of California from 1967 to 1975. During his tenure, he implemented various conservative policies, including tax cuts and reductions in government spending. He also took a hardline stance against student protesters during the 1960s.

#Seeking the presidency (1975–1981)

##1976 Republican primaries

Reagan ran for the Republican presidential nomination in 1976, but lost to incumbent President Gerald Ford. He ran again in 1980 and won the nomination.

##1980 election

Reagan defeated Democratic incumbent Jimmy Carter in the 1980 presidential election, winning 489 electoral votes to Carter's 49.

#Presidency (1981–1989)

##First inauguration

Reagan was inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States on January 20, 1981. In his inaugural address, he emphasized the need for limited government and individual freedom.

##"Reaganomics" and the economy

Reagan's economic policies, known as "Reaganomics," emphasized tax cuts, deregulation, and monetarism. The goal was to stimulate economic growth and reduce inflation.

###Taxation

Reagan signed the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, which reduced tax rates across the board and eliminated many tax loopholes.

###Inflation and unemployment

Reagan's economic policies helped to reduce inflation, which had risen to 14.8% in 1980. Unemployment rates also declined, from 7.5% in 1980 to 5.3% in 1989.

###Government spending

Reagan's administration reduced government spending as a percentage of GDP, from 22.2% in 1981 to 21.2% in 1989.

###Deregulation

Reagan's administration deregulated various industries, including banking, energy, and transportation.

###Deficits

Despite the tax cuts and spending reductions, the federal budget deficit increased during Reagan's presidency, from $73.8 billion in 1980 to $221.3 billion in 1986.

##Assassination attempt

On March 30, 1981, Reagan was shot by John Hinckley Jr. outside the Washington Hilton Hotel in Washington, D.C. Reagan survived the attempt on his life and returned to duty within a few weeks.

##Supreme Court appointments

Reagan appointed two Supreme Court justices during his presidency, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia.

##Public sector labor union fights

Reagan's administration clashed with public sector labor unions, particularly during a 1981 air traffic controllers' strike.

##Civil rights

Reagan's administration was criticized for its handling of civil rights issues, particularly with regards to affirmative action and voting rights.

##War on drugs

Reagan's administration launched a "War on Drugs," which included increased funding for anti-drug programs and stricter penalties for drug offenses.

##Escalation of the Cold War

Reagan's presidency saw a significant escalation of the Cold War, with increased military spending and a more aggressive stance towards the Soviet Union.

##Invasion of Grenada

In 1983, Reagan authorized the invasion of Grenada, a small island nation in the Caribbean, to overthrow a Marxist government.

##1984 election

Reagan defeated Democratic challenger Walter Mondale in the 1984 presidential election, winning 525 electoral votes to Mondale's 13.

##Response to the AIDS epidemic

Reagan's administration was criticized for its slow response to the AIDS epidemic, which emerged during his presidency.

##Addressing apartheid

Reagan's administration opposed economic sanctions against South Africa, which was then ruled by a white minority government that enforced apartheid.

##Libya bombing

In 1986, Reagan authorized a bombing campaign against Libya, in response to Libyan support for international terrorism.

##Iran–Contra affair

Reagan's administration was embroiled in the Iran-Contra affair, in which officials secretly sold arms to Iran and used the proceeds to fund anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua.

##The USS Stark incident

In 1987, an Iraqi missile struck the USS Stark, a U.S. Navy frigate, killing 37 American sailors.

##Soviet decline and thaw in relations

Reagan's presidency saw a significant decline in Soviet power and a thaw in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. In 1987, Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev signed the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which eliminated a class of nuclear missiles.

#Post-presidency (1989–2004)

##Support for Brady Bill

After leaving office, Reagan supported the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act, which imposed a five-day waiting period on handgun purchases.

##Alzheimer's disease

In 1994, Reagan announced that he had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. He died on June 5, 2004, at the age of 93.

##Death and funeral

Reagan's funeral was held on June 11, 2004, at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California. He was buried on the library grounds.

#Legacy

##Historical reputation

Reagan's historical reputation is complex and debated. Some view him as a champion of conservative values and a strong leader who helped to end the Cold War. Others see him as a divisive figure who exacerbated social and economic inequality.

##Political influence

Reagan's presidency had a significant impact on American politics, particularly with regards to the Republican Party. His emphasis on conservative values and limited government has influenced generations of Republican politicians.

article:
The Siege of Mariupol was a prolonged military engagement that took place in Mariupol, Ukraine, from February 24 to May 20, 2022, as part of the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The siege was one of the most devastating urban battles in modern history, resulting in significant loss of life, widespread destruction, and a severe humanitarian crisis.

#Background
Mariupol is a strategic port city located on the Sea of Azov, in the Donetsk Oblast of Ukraine. The city has a population of approximately 450,000 people and is a major industrial and economic hub. Prior to the 2022 Russian invasion, Mariupol was under the control of the Ukrainian government, with the city serving as a crucial supply route for the Ukrainian military.

The conflict in eastern Ukraine began in 2014, following the annexation of Crimea by Russia. Pro-Russian separatists, backed by Russian forces, established the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR), which have been recognized by Russia as independent states. Mariupol, being a key city in the region, has been a focal point of the conflict.

#Advances to Mariupol
##Preliminary shelling and advance on the city
On February 24, 2022, Russian forces launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, with Mariupol being one of the primary targets. Russian artillery and rocket systems began shelling the city, targeting residential areas, hospitals, and critical infrastructure. The initial assault was aimed at weakening Ukrainian defenses and creating an opportunity for Russian ground forces to advance.

##Mariupol surrounded
By February 26, Russian forces had encircled Mariupol, cutting off all major roads and supply routes. The city was effectively under siege, with Ukrainian forces and civilians trapped inside. The Russian military continued to pound the city with artillery and aerial bombardments, causing widespread destruction and civilian casualties.

#Urban advances
##Russian push into the city
On March 1, Russian ground forces began their push into Mariupol, attempting to breach Ukrainian defenses. The urban fighting was intense, with both sides suffering significant losses. Russian forces made slow gains, gradually securing key districts and infrastructure.

##Final pockets of resistance
Despite being vastly outnumbered and outgunned, Ukrainian forces continued to resist, employing guerrilla tactics and ambushes to harass Russian troops. As the siege dragged on, Ukrainian forces became increasingly fragmented, with isolated pockets of resistance holding out in various parts of the city.

#Resistance in the Azovstal steel plant
##Withdrawal to Azovstal
As Russian forces closed in on the city center, Ukrainian forces and civilians retreated to the Azovstal steel plant, a vast industrial complex on the outskirts of Mariupol. The plant, with its extensive underground tunnels and bunkers, provided a secure location for Ukrainian forces to regroup and plan their next move.

##Siege of Azovstal
Russian forces, aware of the strategic importance of Azovstal, launched a concerted effort to capture the plant. Ukrainian forces, however, held firm, employing a combination of artillery, sniper fire, and sabotage to repel Russian attacks.

##Evacuation of civilians
As the siege of Azovstal intensified, humanitarian organizations and Ukrainian authorities worked to evacuate civilians trapped inside the plant. On May 7, a convoy of buses, escorted by United Nations and International Committee of the Red Cross personnel, successfully evacuated over 100 civilians from the plant.

##Ukrainian surrender
On May 20, after weeks of brutal fighting, Ukrainian forces at Azovstal surrendered to Russian troops. The capture of the plant marked the end of organized Ukrainian resistance in Mariupol, with Russian forces securing control of the city.

#Aftermath
##Demolition of buildings and Russification of the city
Following the capture of Mariupol, Russian forces began a systematic campaign to demolish or renovate buildings, erasing Ukrainian cultural and historical symbols. The city's streets were renamed, and Russian language and culture were imposed on the local population.

##Last Ukrainian holdouts and prisoners of war
As Russian forces secured control of Mariupol, they began to round up Ukrainian soldiers and civilians suspected of collaboration with Ukrainian forces. Many were taken prisoner, with some facing trial and imprisonment.

##City government's role
The city government, now under Russian control, played a crucial role in implementing Russian policies and suppressing Ukrainian identity. Local officials were either coerced or replaced with pro-Russian appointees.

##Claimed cholera outbreak
In June 2022, Ukrainian authorities reported a cholera outbreak in Mariupol, claiming that Russian forces had failed to provide adequate sanitation and medical care to the local population. Russian officials denied the allegations, accusing Ukraine of spreading propaganda.

##Ukrainian missile strikes
In response to the capture of Mariupol, Ukrainian forces launched a series of missile strikes against Russian positions in the city. The attacks caused significant damage and casualties, with Russian forces struggling to maintain control.

#Casualties
##Military casualties
Estimates of military casualties vary widely, with both sides suffering significant losses. Ukrainian forces lost hundreds of soldiers, while Russian forces suffered an estimated 1,000 to 2,000 casualties.

##Civilian casualties
The humanitarian toll of the siege was devastating, with thousands of civilians killed or injured. The exact number of civilian casualties remains unknown, but estimates range from 2,000 to 5,000.

#Humanitarian situation

2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts

The 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts was held from February 17 to 26, 2023, at the Sandman Centre in Kamloops, British Columbia. This was the 42nd edition of the Scotties Tournament of Hearts, the national women's curling championship of Canada. The tournament was won by the Kerri Einarson rink from Manitoba, who defeated the Rachel Homan rink from Ontario in the final.

# Teams

Eighteen teams participated in the 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts, including teams from all ten provinces, three territories, and three wild card teams. The teams were:

article:
Francis Drake

Sir Francis Drake (c. 1540 – 28 January 1596) was an English sea captain, privateer, navigator, and explorer of the Elizabethan era. He is best known for being the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe and for his role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada. Drake's exploits made him a hero in England, but his privateering activities also made him a pirate in the eyes of the Spanish.

#Birth and early years

Francis Drake was born around 1540 in Tavistock, Devon, England. His father, Edmund Drake, was a tenant farmer and a Protestant. The family later moved to Kent, where Drake's father became a church deacon. Drake's early education is not well documented, but it is believed that he attended a local school in Kent.

#Early career at sea

Drake began his maritime career at a young age, possibly around 1560. He started as an apprentice on a merchant ship, and over the years, he gained experience and skills as a sailor and navigator.

##Slave trade

In the early 1560s, Drake became involved in the slave trade, sailing to Africa and the Caribbean. He worked for his cousin, Sir John Hawkins, who was a prominent slave trader. During this period, Drake developed skills as a navigator and learned about the Spanish Main, which would later become important in his privateering activities.

##Expedition of 1572–1573

In 1572, Drake and his cousin John Hawkins organized an expedition to the Caribbean. The expedition was intended to attack Spanish ships and colonies, but it ended in disaster when the Spanish attacked their fleet. Drake and Hawkins escaped, but many of their men were killed or captured.

##Rathlin Island massacre

In 1575, Drake participated in the Rathlin Island massacre, in which hundreds of Scottish and Irish villagers were killed by English forces. Drake was part of a privateering expedition led by John Norreys, who was seeking to capture the island from the Scottish.

#Circumnavigation (1577–1580)

Drake's most famous voyage was his circumnavigation of the globe, which took place from 1577 to 1580. The voyage was sponsored by Queen Elizabeth I and was intended to disrupt Spanish shipping and colonies in the Pacific.

##Execution of Thomas Doughty

In 1578, Drake had Thomas Doughty, one of his officers, executed for mutiny. The execution took place on the island of Puerto San Julián in what is now Argentina. Doughty had been accused of plotting against Drake, and his execution was seen as a way to maintain discipline on the ship.

##Entering the Pacific (1578)

In September 1578, Drake's ship, the Golden Hind, entered the Pacific Ocean through the Strait of Magellan. This was the first time an English ship had sailed through the strait.

##Raids on Spanish American west coast

Drake's ship sailed along the Spanish American west coast, raiding towns and ships. He captured several Spanish ships, including the Nuestra Señora de la Victoria, which was carrying a large cargo of gold and silver.

##Coast of California: Nova Albion (1579)

In June 1579, Drake sailed up the coast of California and claimed the land for England, naming it Nova Albion. He and his men spent several weeks in the area, repairing their ship and interacting with the local Native American tribes.

##Across the Pacific and around Africa

After leaving California, Drake's ship sailed across the Pacific and around Africa, returning to England in 1580. The voyage was a major achievement, as Drake had become the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe.

##Return to Plymouth (1580)

Drake returned to Plymouth in September 1580, where he was greeted as a hero. He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I, who was impressed by his achievements.

##Knighthood and arms

Drake was granted a coat of arms, which featured a wyvern (a mythical creature) and the motto "Sic Parvis Magna" ("Thus great things from small beginnings").

#Political career

Drake became involved in politics after his circumnavigation. He was elected as a member of parliament for Plymouth in 1584 and served on several committees.

#Great Expedition to America

In 1585, Drake led an expedition to the Caribbean, which was intended to attack Spanish colonies and shipping. The expedition was successful, and Drake captured several Spanish ships and towns.

#Conflict with the Spanish Armada

Drake played a major role in the conflict with the Spanish Armada, which took place in 1588. The Armada was a large fleet of Spanish ships that was sent to invade England.

##Cádiz raid

In 1587, Drake led a raid on the Spanish port of Cádiz, where he sank several Spanish ships and destroyed much of the port.

##Defeat of the Spanish Armada

In 1588, Drake played a key role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada. He was one of the leaders of the English fleet, which was much smaller than the Spanish fleet. However, the English ships were more maneuverable, and they were able to use their superior gunnery to defeat the Spanish.

##English Armada

In 1589, Drake led an expedition to Spain, which was intended to destroy the Spanish fleet and capture the city of Lisbon. The expedition was unsuccessful, and Drake's ship was forced to retreat.

#Defeats and death

Drake's later years were marked by several defeats and failures. He was defeated by the Spanish in several battles, and he was eventually forced to retreat to England.

Drake died on January 28, 1596, off the coast of Panama. He was buried at sea, and his body was later lost.

#Family and heritage

Drake married twice, first to Mary Newman and then to Elizabeth Sydenham. He had no children, but he had several nieces and nephews who inherited his property and title.

#Legacy and honours

Drake's legacy is still celebrated today. He is remembered as a hero and a pioneer, and his exploits have inspired countless books, films, and other works of art.

##Geographical names

Several geographical features have been named after Drake, including Drake's Passage, which is a strait at the tip of South America, and Drake Bay, which is a bay in California.

article:
Ice Spice

Ice Spice is an American rapper and songwriter from the Bronx, New York. She rose to fame in 2022 with her debut single "Munch (Feelin' U)" and has since become a prominent figure in the hip-hop scene.

#Early life and education

Ice Spice was born Isis Naija Gaston on January 23, 2000, in the Bronx, New York. She grew up in a low-income household with her mother and siblings. Gaston's early life was marked by financial struggles, and she often found solace in music as a way to express herself.

Gaston attended the State University of New York at Purchase, where she studied communications. However, she dropped out of college to pursue a career in music.

#Career

##2021–2022: Career beginnings

Ice Spice began her music career in 2021, performing at local open mic nights and freestyling with friends. She gained a small following on social media platforms, particularly Instagram and TikTok, where she would post videos of herself rapping.

In August 2022, Ice Spice released her debut single "Munch (Feelin' U)," which quickly gained traction online. The song's catchy hook and Ice Spice's confident flow resonated with listeners, and it soon went viral.

##2023–present: Breakthrough with Like…?

In January 2023, Ice Spice released her debut EP, Like…?, which included the hit singles "Munch (Feelin' U)" and "Bikini Bottom." The EP was a commercial success, debuting at number 37 on the US Billboard 200 chart.

The EP's lead single, "In Ha Mood," peaked at number 11 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, making Ice Spice the first female rapper from New York to reach the top 20 since Nicki Minaj. The song's success was fueled by its catchy hook and Ice Spice's witty lyrics, which showcased her storytelling ability.

#Artistry

##Musical and lyrical style

Ice Spice's music is characterized by her confident flow, witty lyrics, and catchy hooks. Her style is heavily influenced by New York hip-hop, with nods to artists such as the Notorious B.I.G. and Jay-Z.

Ice Spice's lyrics often focus on her personal experiences, including her relationships and her rise to fame. She is known for her vivid storytelling ability, which has drawn comparisons to artists such as Slick Rick and Nas.

##Influences

Ice Spice has cited a range of influences, including New York hip-hop legends such as the Notorious B.I.G. and Jay-Z. She has also mentioned being influenced by female rappers such as Lil' Kim and Foxy Brown, who paved the way for her generation of female artists.

#Personal life

##Feuds & controversies

Ice Spice has been involved in several high-profile feuds, including a public dispute with rapper Lil Tjay. The feud began on social media, with both artists exchanging insults and diss tracks.

Ice Spice has also been involved in controversy surrounding her lyrics, which some have criticized for being misogynistic and homophobic. However, Ice Spice has maintained that her lyrics are a reflection of her personal experiences and are not intended to offend.

article:
Coco Lee

Coco Lee (January 17, 1975 – July 5, 2023) was a Hong Kong-born American singer, songwriter, record producer, and actress. Born Ferren Lee, she was one of the most successful and influential Canto-pop artists of all time, known for her powerful vocals, captivating stage presence, and versatility in multiple genres. With a career spanning over three decades, Coco Lee was a trailblazer in the music industry, breaking cultural and linguistic barriers to achieve international recognition.

#Early life

Coco Lee was born Ferren Lee on January 17, 1975, in Hong Kong to a Chinese family. Her parents, both music lovers, encouraged her to pursue music from a young age. She began taking piano lessons at the age of 3 and later learned to play the guitar. Lee's early life was marked by frequent moves between Hong Kong and California, where her family eventually settled. She attended high school in San Francisco and developed a passion for singing, influenced by artists such as Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey.

#Career

##Career beginnings and Sony Music: 1993–1998

Coco Lee's music career began in 1993 when she was discovered by a talent scout while performing at a karaoke bar in San Francisco. She was signed to Sony Music and released her debut album, "Love from Now On," in 1993. The album was moderately successful, but it was her second album, " Promise Me," released in 1994, that brought her widespread recognition in Hong Kong and Taiwan. Lee's powerful vocals and unique style quickly gained her a large following in the Canto-pop scene.

##International collaborations and English debut: 1998–2005

In 1998, Coco Lee collaborated with international artists such as Ricky Martin and Boyzone, which helped her gain exposure in the global music market. She released her English debut album, "CoCo's Party," in 2000, which included the hit single "Wherever You Go." The album was moderately successful, but it marked a significant milestone in Lee's career, as she became one of the first Canto-pop artists to release an English-language album.

##Second English album and Warner Music: 2005–2011

In 2005, Coco Lee signed with Warner Music and released her second English album, "Exposed." The album included the hit singles "No Doubt" and "Hip Hop Tonight." Lee's collaboration with international producers and artists continued to shape her sound, and she became known for her ability to blend different styles and genres.

##New album and final projects before death: 2011–2023

In 2011, Coco Lee released her fifth Mandarin album, "Illuminate," which marked a new era in her career. The album included the hit singles "Party Time" and "Edge of the World." Lee continued to release music and collaborate with other artists until her death in 2023.

#Personal life

Coco Lee was known for her outgoing personality and was often referred to as the "Queen of Canto-pop." She was married to businessman Bruce Rockowitz from 2011 until her death in 2023.

#Health issues

In 2019, Coco Lee revealed that she had been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal cancer, a type of head and neck cancer. She underwent treatment and appeared to be in remission, but her health issues continued to affect her career and personal life.

#Death

Coco Lee passed away on July 5, 2023, at the age of 48, after a long battle with cancer. Her death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from fans and fellow artists around the world.

##Services and tributes

A memorial service was held for Coco Lee in Hong Kong, attended by friends, family, and fellow artists. The service included performances and tributes to Lee's life and legacy.

##Aftermath

The aftermath of Coco Lee's death was marked by an outpouring of grief and tributes from fans and fellow artists. Her legacy as a trailblazing artist and cultural icon continues to be celebrated.

###Leaked clips and Sing! China

In the days following Coco Lee's death, leaked clips of her performances on the Chinese reality TV show "Sing! China" surfaced online. The clips showed Lee's powerful vocals and captivating stage presence, and were widely shared on social media.

#Legacy

Coco Lee's legacy as a trailblazing artist and cultural icon continues to be celebrated. She was a true pioneer in the music industry, breaking cultural and linguistic barriers to achieve international recognition. Her music and legacy continue to inspire new generations of artists and fans.

#Philanthropy

Coco Lee was a dedicated philanthropist and supported various charitable causes throughout her career. She was particularly passionate about supporting cancer research and awareness.

#Artistry

Coco Lee was known for her powerful vocals, captivating stage presence, and versatility in multiple genres. She was a true artist and innovator, always pushing the boundaries of what was possible in music.

article:
2022 Ontario general election

The 2022 Ontario general election was held on June 2, 2022, to elect the 124 members of the 43rd Parliament of Ontario. The election was called on May 4, 2022, by Lieutenant Governor Elizabeth Dowdeswell, on the advice of Premier Doug Ford, and resulted in a majority government for the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario.

Background

The 42nd Parliament of Ontario was elected on June 7, 2018, and was originally set to expire on June 7, 2022. However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Ontario government passed the Protecting Ontario Elections Act, 2020, which extended the term of the 42nd Parliament by one year. This allowed the government to delay the 2022 election until June 2022, rather than having it in the spring.

Timeline

### 2018

The 2018 Ontario general election was held on June 7, 2018, and resulted in a majority government for the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario, led by Doug Ford. The PCs won 76 seats, while the New Democratic Party (NDP), led by Andrea Horwath, won 40 seats, and the Liberal Party of Ontario, led by Kathleen Wynne, won 7 seats.

### 2020

In 2020, the Ontario government passed the Protecting Ontario Elections Act, 2020, which extended the term of the 42nd Parliament by one year. This allowed the government to delay the 2022 election until June 2022, rather than having it in the spring.

### 2021

In 2021, the Ontario NDP and Liberal Party both underwent leadership elections. Marit Stiles became the new leader of the Ontario NDP, while Steven Del Duca became the new leader of the Liberal Party.

### 2022

The 2022 Ontario general election was called on May 4, 2022, by Lieutenant Governor Elizabeth Dowdeswell, on the advice of Premier Doug Ford. The election was set for June 2, 2022.

Campaign period

The campaign period for the 2022 Ontario general election began on May 4, 2022, when the writs were dropped, and ended on June 2, 2022, when the election was held.

### Candidates not standing for reelection

Several MPPs announced that they would not be seeking reelection in 2022. These included:

* Bill Walker (PC)
* Laurie Scott (PC)
* Jim McDonell (PC)
* Randy Pettapiece (PC)
* Belinda Karahalios (Independent)
* Gila Martow (PC)

### Party slogans

* Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario: "Get It Done"
* New Democratic Party: "A New Deal for Ontario"
* Liberal Party of Ontario: "A Fresh Start for Ontario"

### Debates

There were several debates held during the campaign period, including:

* Leaders' debate on May 16, 2022
* Debate on education on May 18, 2022
* Debate on healthcare on May 20, 2022

### Issues

The 2022 Ontario general election campaign focused on several key issues, including:

* Healthcare: The COVID-19 pandemic had highlighted the need for improved healthcare in Ontario, and all three major parties campaigned on improving healthcare services.
* Education: The pandemic had also disrupted education in Ontario, and the parties campaigned on improving education services and supporting teachers.
* Economy: The parties campaigned on their plans to support the economy and create jobs in Ontario.
* Environment: The parties campaigned on their plans to address climate change and protect the environment.

### Summary

The 2022 Ontario general election campaign was marked by a focus on key issues such as healthcare, education, and the economy. The parties campaigned on their plans to address these issues and improve the lives of Ontarians.

### Endorsements

Several organizations and individuals endorsed candidates in the 2022 Ontario general election, including:

* The Toronto Star endorsed the Liberal Party of Ontario
* The Toronto Sun endorsed the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario
* The Ontario Federation of Labour endorsed the New Democratic Party

Opinion polls

### Campaign polls

Several opinion polls were conducted during the campaign period, including:

* A poll conducted by Ipsos on May 6-9, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 37% support, followed by the NDP with 26%, and the Liberals with 26%.
* A poll conducted by Forum Research on May 12-15, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 40% support, followed by the NDP with 25%, and the Liberals with 24%.
* A poll conducted by Nanos Research on May 20-23, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 42% support, followed by the NDP with 27%, and the Liberals with 22%.

### Pre-campaign polls

Several opinion polls were conducted before the campaign period, including:

* A poll conducted by Ipsos on April 15-18, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 35% support, followed by the NDP with 28%, and the Liberals with 26%.
* A poll conducted by Forum Research on April 21-24, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 38% support, followed by the NDP with 26%, and the Liberals with 25%.
* A poll conducted by Nanos Research on April 28-May 1, 2022, which showed the PCs leading with 40% support, followed by the NDP with 28%, and the Liberals with 22%.

Results

### Synopsis of results

The 2022 Ontario general election resulted in a majority government for the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario, led by Doug Ford. The PCs won 83 seats, while the New Democratic Party won 31 seats, and the Liberal Party of Ontario won 8 seats.

### Post-election pendulum

The following is a post-election pendulum, showing the seats that changed hands in the 2022 Ontario general election:

* PC gains from NDP: 10 seats
* PC gains from Liberal: 4 seats
* NDP gains from Liberal: 2 seats
* Liberal gains from NDP: 1 seat

### Results summary by region

The following is a summary of the results by region:

* Northern Ontario: PCs won 11 seats, NDP won 6 seats, Liberals won 2 seats
* Eastern Ontario: PCs won 16 seats, NDP won 4 seats, Liberals won 3 seats
* Central Ontario: PCs won 15 seats, NDP won 5 seats, Liberals won 2 seats
* GTA: PCs won 25 seats, NDP won 10 seats, Liberals won 5 seats
* Southwestern Ontario: PCs won 16 seats, NDP won 6 seats, Liberals won 2 seats

### Detailed results

The following is a detailed breakdown of the results in each riding:

* Riding 1: PCs won with 45.6% support
* Riding 2: NDP won with 42.1% support
* Riding 3: Liberals won with 40.5% support
* ...
* Riding 124: PCs won with 51.2% support

### Summary analysis

The 2022 Ontario general election resulted in a majority government for the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario, led by Doug Ford. The PCs won 83 seats, while the New Democratic Party won 31 seats, and the Liberal Party of Ontario won 8 seats. The PCs made significant gains in the GTA and Southwestern Ontario, while the NDP made gains in Northern Ontario.

### Most marginal 2-way and 3-way contests

The following are the most marginal 2-way and 3-way contests in the 2022 Ontario general election:

* Riding 1: PCs won by 1.2% over NDP
* Riding 2: NDP won by 0.5% over PCs
* Riding 3: Liberals won by 2.1% over PCs and NDP

### Significant results among independent and minor party candidates

* Riding 1: PCs gained from NDP

article:
Vaathi

Vaathi is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action drama film written and directed by Venky Atluri. The film stars Dhanush, Samyuktha Menon, and Sai Kumar in pivotal roles. Vaathi is a bilingual film, simultaneously shot in Tamil and Telugu as Sir.

# Plot

The story revolves around Bala Gangadhar Tilak (Dhanush), a junior lecturer at a government college in Tirunelveli, who becomes a catalyst for change in the lives of his students and the community at large. The film explores themes of social inequality, education, and the struggles of the common man.

Bala Gangadhar Tilak, a passionate and dedicated teacher, takes up a job at a government college in Tirunelveli, where he faces numerous challenges, including inadequate infrastructure, lack of resources, and unmotivated students. Despite these obstacles, he strives to inspire and educate his students, often going beyond the call of duty.

As Bala Gangadhar Tilak gains the trust and respect of his students, he begins to uncover the deep-seated issues afflicting the community, including poverty, corruption, and social injustice. He decides to take a stand and fight for the rights of his students and the community, often putting himself in harm's way.

The film's narrative is driven by Bala Gangadhar Tilak's journey, as he confronts the system, challenges the status quo, and ultimately becomes a symbol of hope and change for those around him.

# Cast

* Dhanush as Bala Gangadhar Tilak
* Samyuktha Menon as Meenakshi
* Sai Kumar as Principal
* Tanikella Bharani as MLA
* Narra Srinivas as Minister
* Hyper Aadi as Thilak's friend
* Shara as Meenakshi's friend
* Rajiv Kanakala as Police Officer

# Production

## Development

The project was announced in November 2021, with Dhanush and Venky Atluri teaming up for the first time. The film was initially titled "Sir" in Telugu, but was later changed to "Vaathi" for the Tamil version. The story is set in the 1990s and explores the themes of education and social inequality.

## Filming

Principal photography began in January 2022 and wrapped up in August 2022. The film was shot in various locations in Tirunelveli, Chennai, and Hyderabad. The crew faced numerous challenges during filming, including the COVID-19 pandemic and harsh weather conditions.

# Music

The film's soundtrack and score were composed by G. V. Prakash Kumar. The music album features five tracks, including the popular single "Vaa Vaathi". The song, sung by Shweta Mohan, became a chart-topper and received widespread critical acclaim.

# Release

## Theatrical

Vaathi was released in theatres on February 17, 2023, in Tamil Nadu and other parts of India. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification.

## Home media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video, which released the film on its platform on March 17, 2023. The satellite rights were sold to Sun TV.

# Reception

Vaathi received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised Dhanush's performance, the film's themes, and the music. The film was also a commercial success, grossing over ₹100 crore at the box office.

# Notes

Vaathi is Dhanush's 50th film and marks a significant milestone in his career. The film's success can be attributed to its relatable themes, engaging storyline, and the performances of the cast.

# References

None

# External links

None

article:
Joe Biden Classified Documents Incident

The Joe Biden classified documents incident refers to the discovery of classified documents in the possession of Joe Biden, the 46th President of the United States. The incident began in November 2022, when Biden's lawyers discovered a batch of classified documents from his time as Vice President at his think tank in Washington, D.C. Subsequent searches revealed additional classified documents at his home in Wilmington, Delaware, and other locations.

# Background

As Vice President from 2009 to 2017, Biden had access to classified information as part of his duties. After leaving office, he established the Penn Biden Center for Diplomacy and Global Engagement, a think tank affiliated with the University of Pennsylvania. The center was housed in a Washington, D.C. office building, where Biden maintained an office. In November 2022, Biden's lawyers began a review of the documents stored at the center, ahead of the lease's expiration.

# Discoveries and Other Developments

## First Batch of Documents

On November 2, 2022, Biden's lawyers discovered a batch of classified documents from his time as Vice President at the Penn Biden Center. The lawyers immediately notified the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), which took custody of the documents. The discovery was not publicly disclosed at the time.

## DOJ Letter to Bob Bauer

On November 4, 2022, the Department of Justice (DOJ) sent a letter to Bob Bauer, Biden's personal attorney, requesting that the President's lawyers not review any further documents at the Penn Biden Center. The DOJ also asked that any additional documents be preserved and turned over to the National Archives.

## Second Batch of Documents

On December 20, 2022, Biden's lawyers discovered a second batch of classified documents at his home in Wilmington, Delaware. The documents were found in a storage room adjacent to the garage. The lawyers immediately notified the DOJ and NARA, and the documents were taken into custody.

## FBI Search of Biden's Wilmington Home

On January 20, 2023, the FBI conducted a search of Biden's Wilmington home, with the President's cooperation. The search was part of the ongoing investigation into the classified documents. The FBI found an additional six items with classification markings, which were taken into custody.

## Other Searches

In addition to the searches at the Penn Biden Center and Biden's Wilmington home, the FBI also conducted searches at the Biden family's vacation home in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware, and at the University of Delaware, where Biden donated his Senate papers.

# Initial Responses

## Biden and His Legal Team

Biden has maintained that he was unaware of the classified documents and has cooperated fully with the investigation. His lawyers have stated that the documents were "inadvertently misplaced" and that they are working to ensure that all classified materials are accounted for.

## Elected Officials

### Republican Elected Officials

Republican lawmakers have called for transparency and accountability in the investigation, with some demanding that Biden be held to the same standard as former President Donald Trump, who is also under investigation for classified documents.

### Democratic Elected Officials

Democratic lawmakers have defended Biden, arguing that he has cooperated with the investigation and that the documents were "inadvertently misplaced."

## Media Analysis

The media has provided extensive coverage of the incident, with some outlets drawing comparisons to the Trump investigation. Analysts have noted that the Biden incident is different, given the President's cooperation and the fact that the documents were discovered and reported by his own lawyers.

## Misinformation

There have been reports of misinformation and conspiracy theories surrounding the incident, with some claiming that Biden intentionally hid the documents or that the investigation is a "witch hunt."

## Discovery of Classified Documents at Mike Pence's Residence

On January 24, 2023, it was reported that classified documents had been discovered at the residence of former Vice President Mike Pence. The documents were found by Pence's lawyers, who immediately notified the National Archives. The discovery has raised questions about the handling of classified materials by former government officials.

# Investigations

## Special Counsel

On January 12, 2023, Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed a special counsel to investigate the Biden classified documents incident. The special counsel, Robert Hur, is a former U.S. Attorney and has extensive experience in handling sensitive investigations.

### Decision That Charges Were Unwarranted

On September 9, 2023, the special counsel announced that charges were unwarranted in the Biden classified documents incident. The special counsel found that Biden had not intentionally mishandled the documents and that there was no evidence of wrongdoing.

### Comments on Biden's Memory

In his report, the special counsel noted that Biden's memory had been a subject of concern during the investigation. However, the special counsel found that there was no evidence to suggest that Biden's memory had played a role in the mishandling of the documents.

## Congressional

Congressional committees have also launched investigations into the Biden classified documents incident. The investigations are ongoing, with lawmakers seeking to determine how the documents were mishandled and what steps can be taken to prevent similar incidents in the future.

# See Also

* Classified information in the United States
* National Archives and Records Administration
* Department of Justice
* FBI
* Presidential records
* Classified document scandals in the United States

article:
2023 PDC World Cup of Darts

The 2023 PDC World Cup of Darts is the 14th edition of the PDC World Cup of Darts, a professional darts tournament organized by the Professional Darts Corporation (PDC). The event will be held from June 15 to June 18, 2023, at the Eissporthalle in Frankfurt, Germany.

#Format

The 2023 PDC World Cup of Darts will feature 40 teams from around the world, each consisting of two players. The teams will compete in a combination of doubles and singles matches, with the winning team being the one that wins the most legs. The tournament will begin with a group stage, followed by a knockout stage.

##Group Stage

The group stage will consist of 10 groups of four teams each. Each team will play the other teams in their group once, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage. The group stage matches will be played in a best-of-nine-legs format, with the winning team being the one that wins five legs.

##Knockout Stage

The knockout stage will consist of the top two teams from each group, plus the two highest-ranked losing teams from the group stage. 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification

The 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification was the qualification process for the 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup, which will be held in Bahrain. The qualification process involved 45 teams from the Asian Football Confederation (AFC) and was played from September to October 2022.

#Format changes

The format of the qualification process was altered from the previous edition. The number of teams participating in the qualification process increased from 44 to 45, and the number of groups increased from 9 to 10. The top team from each group and the five best runners-up advanced to the final tournament.

The draw for the qualification process was held on 24 May 2022 at the AFC House in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The 45 teams were divided into 10 groups of 4 or 5 teams. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the 2018 AFC U-16 Championship and the 2020 AFC U-16 Championship qualification.

Players born on or after 1 January 2006 were eligible to participate in the qualification process.

article:
Battle of Kapyong

The Battle of Kapyong was a pivotal engagement fought during the Korean War, occurring from April 22 to April 25, 1951. The battle took place near the town of Kapyong, located in the Gangwon-do province of South Korea. The conflict involved Australian, Canadian, and New Zealand forces, collectively known as the 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (1 RAR), 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry (2 PPCLI), and the 16th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery, against the Chinese People's Volunteer Army (PVA). This article provides an in-depth examination of the battle, including the military situation, the Chinese Spring Offensive, the defense of Hill 504 by the Australian 3 RAR, the last stand on Hill 677 by the Canadian 2 PPCLI, and the aftermath of the battle.

#Background

##Military situation

In the spring of 1951, the Korean War had reached a stalemate. The United Nations Command (UNC), led by General Matthew Ridgway, had launched a series of operations aimed at pushing the Chinese and North Korean forces back across the 38th parallel. However, the PVA had regrouped and reorganized, and was now preparing to launch a massive counterattack.

The 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (1 RAR), was part of the 28th British Commonwealth Brigade, which was tasked with defending the Kapyong Valley. The valley was a strategic location, as it controlled the main road and rail link between Seoul and the north. The Australians were supported by the 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry (2 PPCLI), and the 16th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery.

#Chinese Spring Offensive

##Preparations

In the weeks leading up to the battle, the PVA had been secretly massing troops and supplies in the mountains surrounding the Kapyong Valley. The Chinese had been observing the UNC's defensive positions and had identified several weaknesses, including the lack of coordination between units and the vulnerability of the roads and supply lines.

##Launch of Chinese Spring Offensive

On April 22, 1951, the PVA launched a massive assault on the UNC's defensive positions, including the 28th British Commonwealth Brigade. The Chinese troops poured into the Kapyong Valley, overwhelming the UNC's forward positions and pushing the defenders back.

##South Korean withdrawal, 22–23 April 1951

As the Chinese advanced, the South Korean forces, who were positioned on the flanks of the 28th British Commonwealth Brigade, began to withdraw. This exposed the Australians and Canadians to attack from the sides and rear, making their defensive positions even more precarious.

#Australian 3 RAR defence of Hill 504, 23–24 April 1951

##Night battle

On the night of April 23, the Australian 3 RAR was tasked with defending Hill 504, a strategic location that controlled the main road through the Kapyong Valley. The Australians had established a series of defensive positions on the hill, including machine gun posts and mortar emplacements.

As the Chinese advanced, the Australians were subjected to a fierce artillery bombardment, followed by a wave of infantry attacks. The Australians held their ground, but the Chinese continued to press the attack, using their superior numbers to try and overwhelm the defenders.

##Day battle

On the morning of April 24, the Chinese launched a fresh assault on the Australian positions. The Australians were subjected to a withering artillery bombardment, followed by a series of infantry attacks. The Australians held their ground, but the Chinese continued to press the attack, using their superior numbers to try and overwhelm the defenders.

##3 RAR withdraws

As the day wore on, the Australians began to run low on ammunition and supplies. The Chinese were also starting to make gains on the flanks, threatening to cut off the Australian withdrawal route. In the face of overwhelming odds, the Australians were forced to withdraw from Hill 504, falling back to a new defensive position.

#Canadian 2 PPCLI last stand on Hill 677, 24–25 April 1951

##Preparations

As the Australians withdrew from Hill 504, the Canadian 2 PPCLI was tasked with defending Hill 677, a strategic location that controlled the main road through the Kapyong Valley. The Canadians had established a series of defensive positions on the hill, including machine gun posts and mortar emplacements.

##Night battle

On the night of April 24, the Chinese launched a fierce assault on the Canadian positions. The Canadians were subjected to a withering artillery bombardment, followed by a wave of infantry attacks. The Canadians held their ground, but the Chinese continued to press the attack, using their superior numbers to try and overwhelm the defenders.

##Final 2 PPCLI Operations

As the night wore on, the Canadians began to run low on ammunition and supplies. The Chinese were also starting to make gains on the flanks, threatening to cut off the Canadian withdrawal route. In the face of overwhelming odds, the Canadians were forced to withdraw from Hill 677, falling back to a new defensive position.

#Aftermath

##Summary and casualties

The Battle of Kapyong was a costly and bloody engagement, with both sides suffering heavy casualties. The UNC lost over 1,000 men killed or wounded, while the PVA lost an estimated 10,000 men.

##Awards

The bravery and sacrifice of the Australian and Canadian soldiers during the Battle of Kapyong were recognized with the award of several decorations, including the Victoria Cross, the Distinguished Service Order, and the Military Cross.

##Subsequent operations

The Battle of Kapyong marked a turning point in the Korean War, as the UNC was able to regroup and reorganize following the battle. The UNC launched a series of counterattacks, pushing the PVA back across the 38th parallel and eventually leading to the signing of the Armistice Agreement in July 1953.

article:
The Peel Group
================

The Peel Group is a British conglomerate with interests in a wide range of sectors, including real estate, infrastructure, transportation, energy, and media. Founded in 1971 by John Whittaker, the company has grown to become one of the largest and most influential private companies in the United Kingdom.

History
--------

### Name and listings

The company was founded in 1971 as Peel Holdings by John Whittaker, a British businessman. The name "Peel" comes from the Lancashire town of Peel, where Whittaker's family had a long history. In 2004, the company was rebranded as The Peel Group, reflecting its expanded scope and interests. The company is privately owned, with John Whittaker serving as its chairman.

### Early acquisitions

The Peel Group's early growth was driven by strategic acquisitions in the property and infrastructure sectors. In the 1970s and 1980s, the company acquired several smaller businesses, including a number of quarries and construction companies. These acquisitions provided the foundation for the company's later expansion into new sectors.

### Manchester Ship Canal

One of The Peel Group's most significant early acquisitions was the Manchester Ship Canal, a major transportation artery in northwest England. The company acquired the canal in 1987, and has since invested heavily in its modernization and expansion. Today, the Manchester Ship Canal is one of the busiest inland waterways in the world.

### Trafford Centre

In 1998, The Peel Group opened the Trafford Centre, a massive shopping and leisure complex in Greater Manchester. The Trafford Centre is one of the largest shopping centers in the UK, with over 280 stores and attractions. The complex has been a major success, generating significant revenue for the company.

### Airports

The Peel Group has also invested in the airport sector, acquiring several smaller airports in the UK. In 2001, the company acquired Liverpool Airport, which has since been rebranded as Liverpool John Lennon Airport. The company has also acquired airports in Durham and Doncaster.

### Ports

In addition to its airport interests, The Peel Group has also invested in the port sector. The company has acquired several smaller ports in the UK, including the Port of Liverpool and the Port of Heysham.

### MediaCityUK

In 2007, The Peel Group announced plans to develop MediaCityUK, a major media and technology complex in Salford, Greater Manchester. The complex, which opened in 2011, is home to several major media companies, including the BBC and ITV.

### Pinewood Studios

In 2011, The Peel Group acquired Pinewood Studios, one of the UK's largest film and television production studios. The company has invested heavily in the studio's modernization and expansion, making it one of the most popular production facilities in the world.

### Energy

The Peel Group has also invested in the energy sector, acquiring several smaller energy companies and developing new renewable energy projects. In 2012, the company announced plans to develop a major biomass energy plant in the UK.

### Retail and leisure

In addition to its Trafford Centre complex, The Peel Group has also invested in several other retail and leisure projects. The company has developed several shopping centers and leisure complexes across the UK, including the Liverpool One complex in Liverpool.

### Housing

The Peel Group has also invested in the housing sector, developing several new residential projects across the UK. The company has built thousands of new homes, including several major developments in Liverpool and Manchester.

Business structure

Money in the Bank is an annual event that was established in 2010. The event is centered around two ladder matches, one for the men and one for the women, where the winner earns a contract for a world championship match at a time and place of their choosing within the next year. The event has become a staple of the WWE calendar and is often considered one of the most exciting and unpredictable events of the year.

Merrion Castle and other Cruys holdings
--------------------------------------

The Cruys family held a significant portfolio of lands and castles in Ireland, with their primary seat being Merrion Castle, located in what is now County Dublin. Merrion Castle was a strategic stronghold, situated near the coast and controlling access to the surrounding countryside. The castle was likely built by John's ancestors in the 13th century and served as the family's principal residence and power base.

In addition to Merrion Castle, the Cruys family held lands and castles in other parts of Ireland, including County Kildare and County Wicklow. These holdings were scattered throughout the countryside, reflecting the family's influence and reach across the region.

Career
-------

He quickly rose through the ranks, demonstrating his administrative skills and earning the trust of his superiors. In 1315, he was appointed as the escheator of Ireland, a position that gave him responsibility for managing the crown's lands and revenues in the country.

As escheator, Cruys played a crucial role in the governance of Ireland, working closely with the justiciar and other senior officials to maintain order and collect taxes. He was also involved in the administration of justice, serving as a justice of the peace and hearing cases in the royal courts.

The Verdon inheritance

Through his marriage, Cruys gained control of the Verdon lands and castles, significantly expanding his family's influence and power in Ireland. The Verdon inheritance also brought him closer to the English crown, as the Verdons had long been loyal supporters of the monarchy.

Later career

In the 1320s, John Cruys continued to serve the English crown, holding various positions and responsibilities. He was appointed as the constable of Dublin Castle, a key stronghold in the heart of the city, and played a role in the administration of justice, serving as a justice of the peace.

Cruys also became increasingly involved in the governance of Ireland, serving as a member of the Irish council and advising the justiciar on matters of state. article:
2022 United States Senate elections

The 2022 United States Senate elections were held on November 8, 2022, with 34 of the 100 seats in the Senate being contested. The elections were part of the 2022 United States elections and were held concurrently with the 2022 United States House of Representatives elections and various state and local elections.

# Partisan composition

The partisan composition of the Senate prior to the elections was 50 Republicans, 48 Democrats, and 2 Independents who caucus with the Democrats. The Democrats held a slim majority, with Vice President Kamala Harris casting tie-breaking votes as President of the Senate.

# Summary results

## Seats

Democrats: 48
Republicans: 49
Independents: 3

## Votes

Total votes cast: approximately 104 million
Turnout: approximately 47% of eligible voters

# Closest races

Several Senate races were highly competitive and close, with some results not being finalized until days or weeks after the election. Some of the closest races included:

* Pennsylvania: John Fetterman (D) defeated Mehmet Oz (R) by a margin of 0.5%
* Arizona: Mark Kelly (D) defeated Blake Masters (R) by a margin of 3.1%
* Nevada: Catherine Cortez Masto (D) defeated Adam Laxalt (R) by a margin of 0.8%
* Georgia: Raphael Warnock (D) defeated Herschel Walker (R) by a margin of 1.1% in the runoff election

# Change in composition

## Before the elections

The partisan composition of the Senate before the elections was:

* Democrats: 48
* Republicans: 50
* Independents: 2

## After the elections

The partisan composition of the Senate after the elections was:

* Democrats: 48
* Republicans: 49
* Independents: 3

## Beginning of the first session

The 118th Congress convened on January 3, 2023, with the Senate's partisan composition remaining the same as after the elections.

# Final pre-election predictions

Many election forecasters and analysts made predictions about the outcome of the Senate elections in the days leading up to the election. Some of the final predictions included:

* The Cook Political Report: Democrats would hold 48-50 seats
* The Rothenberg Political Report: Democrats would hold 47-50 seats
* Sabato's Crystal Ball: Democrats would hold 48-50 seats
* RealClearPolitics: Democrats would hold 48-50 seats

# Gains and holds

## Retirements

Several Senators announced their retirement prior to the elections, including:

* Richard Burr (R-NC)
* Pat Toomey (R-PA)
* Rob Portman (R-OH)
* Richard Shelby (R-AL)
* Roy Blunt (R-MO)
* John Boozman (R-AR)
* Jim Inhofe (R-OK)

## Resignations

Two Senators resigned from office prior to the elections:

* Jim Risch (R-ID) resigned on September 1, 2022, to focus on his gubernatorial campaign
* Pat Leahy (D-VT) resigned on November 28, 2022, due to health issues

## Post-election changes

No Senators changed parties or resigned after the elections.

# Race summary

## Special elections during the preceding Congress

Several special elections were held during the 117th Congress, including:

* 2021 California's 22nd congressional district special election
* 2021 Ohio's 11th congressional district special election
* 2021 Texas's 6th congressional district special election

## Elections leading to the next Congress

The following table summarizes the Senate elections by state:

# Alabama

Richard Shelby (R-AL) retired and was succeeded by Katie Britt (R-AL).

# Alaska

Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) won re-election, defeating Kelly Tshibaka (R-AK) in the primary and Pat Chesbro (D-AK) in the general election.

# Arizona

Mark Kelly (D-AZ) won re-election, defeating Blake Masters (R-AZ) in the general election.

# Arkansas

John Boozman (R-AR) won re-election, defeating Natalie James (D-AR) in the general election.

# California

Alex Padilla (D-CA) won re-election, defeating Mark Meuser (R-CA) in the general election.

# Colorado

Michael Bennet (D-CO) won re-election, defeating Joe O'Dea (R-CO) in the general election.

# Connecticut

Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) won re-election, defeating Leora Levy (R-CT) in the general election.

# Florida

Marco Rubio (R-FL) won re-election, defeating Val Demings (D-FL) in the general election.

# Georgia

Raphael Warnock (D-GA) won re-election, defeating Herschel Walker (R-GA) in the runoff election.

# Hawaii

Mazie Hirono (D-HI) won re-election, defeating Bob McDermott (R-HI) in the general election.

# Idaho

Mike Crapo (R-ID) won re-election, defeating David Roth (D-ID) in the general election.

# Illinois

Tammy Duckworth (D-IL) won re-election, defeating Kathy Salvi (R-IL) in the general election.

# Indiana

Todd Young (R-IN) won re-election, defeating Thomas McDermott (D-IN) in the general election.

# Iowa

Chuck Grassley (R-IA) won re-election, defeating Michael Franken (D-IA) in the general election.

# Kansas

Jerry Moran (R-KS) won re-election, defeating Mark Holland (D-KS) in the general election.

# Kentucky

Rand Paul (R-KY) won re-election, defeating Charles Booker (D-KY) in the general election.

# Louisiana

John Kennedy (R-LA) won re-election, defeating Gary Chambers (D-LA) in the general election.

# Maryland

Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) won re-election, defeating Chris Chaffee (R-MD) in the general election.

# Missouri

Eric Schmitt (R-MO) won the open seat, defeating Trudy Busch Valentine (D-MO) in the general election.

# Nevada

Catherine Cortez Masto (D-NV) won re-election, defeating Adam Laxalt (R-NV) in the general election.

# New Hampshire

Maggie Hassan (D-NH) won re-election, defeating Don Bolduc (R-NH) in the general election.

# New York

Chuck Schumer (D-NY) won re-election, defeating Joe Pinion (R-NY) in the general election.

# North Carolina

Ted Budd (R-NC) won the open seat, defeating Cheri Beasley (D-NC) in the general election.

# North Dakota

John Hoeven (R-ND) won re-election, defeating Katrina Christiansen (D-ND) in the general election.

# Ohio

J.D. Vance (R-OH) won the open seat, defeating Tim Ryan (D-OH) in the general election.

# Oklahoma

## Oklahoma (regular)

James Lankford (R-OK) won re-election, defeating Madison Horn (D-OK) in the general election.

## Oklahoma (special)

Markwayne Mullin (R-OK) won the special election, defeating Kendra Horn (D-OK) in the general election.

# Oregon

Ron Wyden (D-OR) won re-election, defeating Jo Rae Perkins (R-OR) in the general election.

# Pennsylvania

John Fetterman (D-PA) won the open seat, defeating Mehmet Oz (R-PA) in the general election.

# South Carolina

Tim Scott (R-SC) won re-election, defeating Krystle Matthews (D-SC) in the general election.

# South Dakota

John Thune (R-SD) won re-election, defeating Brian Bengs (D-SD) in the general election.

# Utah

Mike Lee (R-UT) won re-election, defeating Evan McMullin (I-UT) in the general election.

# Vermont

Bernie Sanders (I-VT) won re-election, defeating Gerald Malloy (R-VT) in the general election.

# Washington

Patty Murray (D-WA) won re-election, defeating Tiffany Smiley (R-WA) in the general election.

# Wisconsin

Ron Johnson (R-WI) won re-election, defeating Mandela Barnes (D-WI) in the general election.

# Notes

This article is a factual summary of the 2022 United States Senate elections.
